They were all amazing in their own roles. Special mention must be made of Evan Peters﻿. No matter how weird the costume looks, his take on Quicksilver was awesome. Not only was his prison break scene one of the coolest slo-mo scenes we've ever witnessed but one of the best scenes in the entire franchise. But yes, the future scenes could've been a little longer. The little details here and there throughout the movie were really good. And of course, Peter Dinklage was really good. The 'future' scenes weren't that long, but the Sentinels were kickass. All in all it was arguably the best movie of the franchise. Now that Singer is back, and X-Men: The Last Stand﻿ is *SPOILER* gone, hopes are sky high for X-Men: Apocalypse﻿.P.S. Watch out for the last scene in the future. Everyone who we lost, are back! Also, the post credits scene. EN SABAH NUR! EN SABAH NUR! EN SABAH NUR!4/5Oh and FYI, John F. Kennedy﻿ was, apparently, a mutant :P

reviews.review_title: The best of all Marvel Films ever created
reviews.content: This movie is better than all marvel movies, even better than marvel avengers. But somehow those have not seen the prequels will rate this movie 7 or 8 on 10. Everything in this movie is related to all the previous xmen series. Bryan Singer's best overall performance in marvel films. Casting was excellent as usual, Hugh Jackman the best suited as Wolverine's physique and style and wonderful performances by Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellen, lets not forget James Avoy who acted exceptionally according to the situation. Bryan Singers and the story writers pushed this movie plot very well along with the previous prequels. Little to much of violence and special effects, but what can we say when there are mutants? Excellent correlation of movie plot. All those who haven't watched the previous prequels, I suggest them to watch xmen, xmen2 , xmen the last stand, xmen origin wolverine and xmen first class for the best experience of a sequel ever. Trust me that this movie is better to watch as sequel rather than watching it as a first film. (To be honest I enjoyed this sequel more than lord of the rings 3). So hurry up and watch the film and rate this movie it IMDb for an 8, 9 or a 10 and create wonderful filmy memory.

Watched XMen: Days of future past last night. A very well produced film and the costume/design guys done a great job between the future and the past. The story a good idea but (for me) they just dragged it out 20mins too much without ever adding any more real substance to what we already knew. The big scenes stole the show and the storyline 'stitching' and character interactions, developments, back stories fell a bit to the wayside. You always know they going to be OK (as already signed up for the next xmen film) so you watch a film in very much a different way as know the expected ending before the film even starts. A good film in the series but Xmen: First Class still my favourite one to date.

When you go to watch this movie, don't buy popcorn at first. Instead buy it sometime in the future, travel back to that very moment and gift yourself the popcorn. I implemented this strategy and ended up watching the movie on an empty stomach. The point of this exercise? Nothing, just as the senseless time travel shown in the film. This much anticipated installment in an otherwise brilliant series will leave you disappointed. That is, unless you choose not to strain your brain and just accept the events as they are. The film opens in a dark and desolate future that was set in motion in 1973, when brilliant scientist Dr. Bolivar Trask (Peter Dinklage) created a series of giant robots called Sentinels for the sole purpose of wiping out mutants, whom he claimed were a direct threat to the human race. Prof. Xavier (Patrick Stewart) and Magneto (Ian McKellen) devise a plan to have Kitty Pryde (Ellen Page) send Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) back to the year when Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence) assassinated Trask -- it turns out that Mystique inadvertently accelerated the Sentinel program when she was subsequently captured by Sgt. William Stryker (Josh Helman), who succeeded at harvesting her DNA to make the robots more powerful than ever before. Upon arriving in the past, Wolverine sets out to change the future. In the end, the viewers are left hanging with a dilemma about the fate of the dystopian future world. It seems as if it never existed. However, if it didn't exist, none of the events in the movie would have occurred in the first place. There are plenty of other loopholes and inconsistencies that will constantly bug an observant viewer. The movie also leaves some open questions, which I hope will be resolved in the future. For example, where does a mutant who can walk through walls (Kitty) get the power to transport people back in time? How did Wolverine get his metal claws back in the future, given that he lost them in the fifth installment? How did Xavier survive the violent disintegration previously seen in the series? On the bright side, some well directed action scenes, especially when Quicksilver saves everyone in slow motion, provides the much needed excitement one expects from an X-Men film. Towards the end, all you can hope is for the next installment, X Men: Apocalypse to be much more sensible, thrilling and satisfying than this movie.

I don't know if it's just me, or X-Men franchises has been overplayed since First Class, or maybe even prior to that. All I know is that Wolverine's badassness has been quite overplayed to the point that it became boring to see Hugh Jackman with that wolfy sideburns and fork hands.I actually wanted to elaborate it with a long narrative text, but it might become as boring as Wolverine. So, I'll make it simple.*SPOILER ALERT*First thing that annoyed me most is that too many anomalies for a franchise that's supposed to stand in-between First Class and its predecessors. It's as if all those stories were all afterthought just for the sake of prolonging the franchises. Here's my list of those anomalies that I found rather annoying and raised too many question marks for my likings:One, Xavier's supposed to be limp, but the producer knew that people wouldn't want to see the oh-so-good-looking James McAvoy sitting around on a wheelchair throughout the movie. Badass protagonist should stand side-by-side with his equally badass partner, or face- to-face with his equally badass enemy. So, here comes the so-called medication for his spine.Two, Xavier's way too invincible. Well, who wouldn't if you have telepathy and super-telekinetic power to even control the time? The producer surely realized it and toned down his character heavily. So, here comes the so-called side-effect.Three, Mystique's the rogue, strong-willed, one-man-army femme fatale... where the hell did that come from? Wasn't Mystique supposed to be loyal to Magneto in the prequels? People changes, sure, but I think the producers were more considering about Lawrence's popularities in her role as Katniss and kinda overplayed this. So, here comes the rogue, strong-willed, one-man-army femme fatale.Four, the producer thought that too many unimportant and less-badass characters like the poor Azazel or Banshee (which, unfortunately, weren't as good-looking as Summers and McCoy) , and they got rid of them... just like what? Like photos in a specimen report? I liked Azazel, though. And whatever the deal with the girl with power just like Banshee?Five, Magneto was imprisoned in a bunker prison with advanced security and plastic bullets. Whatever happened to the less-advanced prison where the older-Magneto was held captive in X2?Six, is it just me, or the technologies in X-Men franchise are becoming more and more advanced every time newer franchise's out. Like technologies in X2 were more advanced than that in X-Men, and The Last Stand was more advanced than its prequels. And First Class was even more advanced, which was supposed to set prior to the other three. And then they have these plastic transformers in Days of Future Past? What the heck...?Seven, Sentinel is T-1000 as in The Terminator. No further comments needed.Eight, what was Kitty's power again? I thought playing with time was Xavier's forte? Can anyone please explain?Nine, All those machine guns and no dead bodies? Please, is this Disney?Ten, (for me) "changing the past" is the worst solution a writer could ever think of. S/he might be wanting to prolong his/her story, or already running out of idea for solution. "Going into the future" sounds less-confusing than "changing the past", seriously. Whenever I watch movies that revolves around "changing the past" theme, I'd always think of what becomes the today's world once the history has changed? Perished like dust, then replaced with the already-changed- history version of today's world?Okay, this could go on forever if I continue on with this. All those point I wrote were mostly taken from the first half of the movie. I could write a book if I list every anomalies in the entire movie. You should watch it yourself and see my points, or so I hope.Overally, I enjoyed X-Men; Days of Future Past as some mindless-but- cool action movie, nothing much. If you don't wonder much about various unnecessary details, and if you haven't watched the prequels, you might find yourself happy that you've watched it. But if you do wonder about various unnecessary details, and at some point have watched the prequels, you might find yourself confused throughout the movie.

reviews.review_title: Better than I expected, still wanted more...but maybe that's a good thing!
reviews.content: Like most X-Men fans, my support of the X-Men franchise has always been rocky for a number of reasons but I won't get into that because those explanations have been exhausted through the years. But, I've always remained optimistic and First Class and The Wolverine are the main reasons why I was excited to see this film because I had almost given up and I'm glad I didn't. DOFP is everything it was supposed to be, although it lacks in areas, the overall result was an amazing experience from beginning to end.The Bad: I understand why they focused more on the 70s era but I wish we saw more of the dystopian future. I wanted to at least see some character interaction between all the X-Men in the future. All of the characters served their purpose enough for me to want to see more, but I mean we could have at least gotten some more dialogue between them all. I've come to the conclusion that Storm will never get her just do. I have many questions about where the franchise will go but I don't think that's necessarily a bad thing it just means that I am anxious to see more movies. Too many characters are introduced just for show, but what can you do. *sigh*The Good: The time travel element is not confusing at all. The script is solid and there aren't any cheesy scenes or bad dialogue. Visual effects are amazing. Seeing everyone use their powers and how they work together was totally fun to watch. It was great seeing how Charles becomes Professor X. James McAvoy's performance was so compelling. Opening sequence was on the same caliber as the opening sequence in X2 with Nightcrawler. Everyone's performance and it was nice to see that Wolverine wasn't the main focal point. The Sentinels are scary as hell and everything just builds to be great. I'm not sure how to really reviews this film without giving spoilers, but you can tell that Bryan Singer and Simon Kinberg really took their time in structuring a well crafted movie. It combines science fiction and action with depth and emotion very well and that's what I think a comic book movie should be about.My faith in the franchise has been restored and all the ester eggs moments and possibilities they can do with the franchise makes me very excited for what's coming next. I just have to say that after X-Men: Apocalypse, I don't want to see anymore origin movies. I want to see a full on X- Men movie. Avengers managed to give us an amazing spectacle of what a team up battle should look like. DOFP delivered but the climax is nowhere near as Epic as Avengers was but I'm fine with that because DOFP did it's job and I'm ready for more.This is definitely the best X-Men movie of he franchise.

reviews.review_title: The only x-men film I enjoyed/liked to date (may have spoiling element)
reviews.content: Like the title of my summary states; in my eyes this one stands alone (timeline aside). The fact that both sides had to get together to defeat a new enemy always was my favorite part about x-men because tensions rise and your always left to wonder will there be a catch, does one side have a secret element which will put them at an advantage. Realizing it was done in the other films yet specifically in this one there's so much tension your thinking: if there is an alternate plan from one of the sides how can they withhold that in this situation. Plus they finally brought in some intense challengers other than the usual brotherhood vs x-men.

You guys should really stop looking for the bad in every single superhero movie. This movie is by far THE BEST X-MEN MOVIE OF ALL TIME. Many of you guys may disagree. People who are comic book freaks will complain about Wolverine going back in time instead of Kitty like in the comics. Others will complain that the dialogue of the movie is terribly scripted and that there isn't enough action. Well, the only reasonable excuse is the first one the comic book freaks may have. The other ones are all completely false.Many people come here and write bad reviews purposely because they complain about everything and try to find the bad in everything because they themselves aren't happy with their lives. These are known as "Haters" for those who don't already know. Do not trust these guys.X-Men:Days of Future Past is indeed a wonderful movie. I highly suggest you see it if you have not already. Great story, wonderful acting, great fighting scenes, amazing heroes (both old and new), and of course the great and sexy Jennifer Lawrence at it again. My favorite addition were the scenes with Quicksilver. Too bad he couldn't have stuck around for the whole movie, but I sense he will be back in future X-Men movies. I hope they will be just as good or possibly better than this one.Well, I hope you guys who haven't yet seen the movie will seriously consider seeing it. I saw it in 3D, which really isn't necessary but it put the movie in a whole new dimension! (Get it? Dimension?) The movie would have been just as amazing if I didn't see it in 3D. Well, stop reading this review and see the movie. NOW!

The X-Men franchise Brian Singer started, delivered us two great movies before spiraling a path downwards. X3 - the first X-Movie without Singer writing or directing - did not have what it takes storywise and had a mishmash of a plot. "X-Men Origins: Wolverine" is a movie best to be forgotten, almost bringing the X-franchise to its death. Then, with "First Class" and "The Wolverine" a road to redemption was taken, and reached its destiny in "Days of Future Past".It's a thrill from beginning to end. Hearing the original theme music again felt like coming home, and then the movie itself: excellent.We meet some new mutants, some familiar mutants, and however some of them gets cast aside too quickly - none of them feel redundant. The movie provides us lots of action, without stalling plot advancements.Offcourse, it's not a flawless movie. It is never explained how Kitty Pryde acquired her new skill to send peoples minds into younger versions of themselves. Again, it's a Wolverine-centered movie... Apart from "first class" he never gets to take a back seat and thus upstaging other mutants. Granted, the plot points out a necessity for him to be the one who time-travels. And even with the time traveling, some of the plot holes established in earlier movies were not fixed.However, in itself, this movie is brilliant. And even if not all plot holes get fixed, at least you leave the theater feeling that they did. Elaborating on all this brings me into spoiler territory, which is where I don't want to go. I would love for you to go see it and form your own opinion. Go do that now!

reviews.review_title: Fattest Mystique, Casting Ruined Prequel to a Great Original X-men Trilogy, Reason I think for such bad casting choice inside the review.
reviews.content: If you seen original X-men trilogy Rebecca Romjin personified Mystique perfectly any true geek could rave about it for hours how she was supple, agile, mercurial and rubber like she was imagined to be. Superhero movies like any other good fantasy fiction have to be best make believe as it can be especially each character. Here comes prequel movie series to original Classic X-men movies with The First Class and we get Fattest Mystique anybody could imagine Jennifer Lawrence, it was disrespect to the character. I mean how did she land the character in 1st place, she could never be the actor that would come to anybody's mind when imagining the cast. Even let us say Jennifer Lawrence comes to audition how could somebody of her physique would pass the audition, what did she do for casting folks to overlook the main aspect the character. Only thing that comes to mind would be casting couch which Hollywood biggies don't like to talk about and boy she must be really good at it too. If you seen the movie she in pure Mystique form she looked more like somebody who ate Mystique rather than the supple mutant, considering she was also actress who played main lead in " The Hunger Games" around same time didn't seem to one prepared for that. Sorry if you think I am being disrespectful but as a absolute geek I was hurt when they disrespected the character by that casting choice. Even the best way she used to show Mystique's physical ability herself without a body double was by doing that side squat bend like if you remember when she did when she was on table in Paris hiding behind Xavier from Magneto.The height of Jennifer Lawrence worship is so extreme that the complete story concept was changed, Mystique powers just mimicked to look like somebody not take their powers. So same way the sentinels made from her DNA wouldn't be powerful with powers but just mimics. Now that was big goof but now the director knew that therefore made a Rogue Cut.This all really ruined the movie for me cause like I said before Superhero movies all the actor must look the character more so than any other movie type. Some folks might argue she is acts well but they surely could find somebody who acts well and actually would fit the look and physique. I do appreciate she slimmed down a lot by third installment of the movie series but then there were even worse casting goofs in that movie.But since the movie is from amazing original X-men storyline and hence got a hit but would have been bigger hit if the makers had been sincere.

Days of Future Past is a film that is really ambitious! It gave a lot of thrill and stakes, but the time travel element is both good and bad for this film. Sometimes I was confused as to what is happening, but in the end, I enjoyed the film. Not the best thing in the world, but it was fun to watch.

Is days of future past the best Xmen movie so far? Let's look backXmen: This was a good film it introduced each of the main characters. The action was not as good as what we see in the films to come but still has enough to keep you interested.Xmen 2: They really gave this film everything and left you wanting more. The opening scene was great and Wolverine's fight scene in the school was brutal. What really worked well was seeing the mutants come together to take on a new enemy and no one knew how to feel about the ending.Xmen The Last Stand: This film receives a lot of criticism and in some part deserves it. The story was not that bad, but the execution was terrible. The number of deaths to key characters was what I feel let it down. Remember to watch the final scene after the credits.Xmen Origins Wolverine: I enjoyed this film, well the first 70 minutes of it. Seeing Wolverine grow up with Sabretooth was interesting.( even tho he was never referred to as Sabretooth) The thing that bought this film down was Dead Pool. Their version of him was really really bad and the final fight scene on top of the reactor was a big letdown. Xmen First Class: The introduction of a younger Magneto and Professor X was great. Michael Fassbender stole the show and James McAvoy was a great Proffossor X. Kevin Bacon as the villain was at his usual best and Jennifer Lawrence casting as Raven was fantastic. There was less action in this film than any other Xmen movie but the storyline made up for that.The Wolverine: The 2nd outing with Hugh Jackmans standalone Xmen film. This was much better than his first attempt. He really looked the part and the action in this film was amazing. The fight scene on the bullet train is simply a must see. The film was based in Japan and there were a few people who didn't like that but I thought it was great. This film is considered the most violent of the Xmen films so far. Now Xmen Days of Future Past: This is a very different Xmen movie based straight from the Xmen cartoon. There were some slight changes but I feel the changes they made where necessary and improved the film. There was a good balance of action vs storyline here which I feel hasn't been done in an Xmen film since X2. The way they explained the time travel was done simply and easy which most people will understand. The introduction of quicksilver was a highlight of the film. So is Xmen Days of Future Past the best Xmen film I would have to say YES but running a close 2nd is Xmen 2.

X men days of future past: this film is basically a awesome and ballsy retelling of x men. Now this was only the 2nd x men film I saw, and I was too young to really remember it. So seeing this just blew my mind. I think the clinchers were how they picked up and moved an entire stadium, and of course the quicksilver scene. But god I wish there was more of quicksilver. Hell give him his own spin off, fanboys help me with this it needs to happen. But anyways, 8.9 for the truly kick ass film. If you enjoyed this review, be sure to check out my YouTube channel Quinn C (the one with the James Bond emblem). I review films old and new, as well as take in depth looks at the James Bond series. If you like film at all, in particular James Bond, please be sure to check me out on Quinn C (with the James Blnd emblem) on YouTube. Thanks

reviews.review_title: Bryan Singer makes a spectacular movie and says F**k Brett Radner at the same time.
reviews.content: Me personally, a huge XMEN fan, had high expectations for XMEN days of future past. Not only did this blow out my expectations, it made me feel amazed. The movie has A+ acting, A+ casting, A+ storyline, A+ special effects. The movie made you have a personal connection with each character and feel for the character. There were no forced characters and each person had an important role in the storyline. To fully understand this movie you need to see basically every XMEN movie. spoiler. Bryan Singer says f**k you Brett Radner in this spectacular installment of the XMEN series. After Logan(wolverine) goes back in time and saves the day, he awakes in his present body at Charles Xavier's School for gifted youngsters and is amazed to see that the plan actually worked and everyone is alive. But as he turns around he sees a fully healthy Jean Gray due to the fact that Days Of Future Past makes the events that occurred in the original trilogy irrelevant. After being overwhelmed with emotion Logan goes to kiss Jean Gray, and what do you know....... Scott summers yes Scott summers Cyclops stops him. Both of these characters died in X3 last stand from the godforsaken directing of a**hole Brett Radner. On that note XMEN DAYS OF FUTURE PAST is one of my favorite movies of all time and i give it a 10/10.

reviews.review_title: My All Time Favorite Superhero Movie
reviews.content: Introduction:Before I start my review I will do The Pros' N Cons'.Acknowledge: The Cast, Directors, Producers, Budget, Acclaim, Box Office Earning, Rating, and etc.Just overall background information which you may/may not of known about the film.Pros': The Cast:Hugh Jackman as Wolverine James McAvoy/Patrick Stewart as Young/Old Charles Xavier Michael Fassbender/Ian McKellen as Magneto Jennifer Lawrence as MystiqueHalle Berry as Storm Nicholas Hoult/Kelsey Grammar as Hank McCoy/Beast Anna Paquin as Rogue Ellen Page as Kitty Pryde/Shadowcat Peter Dinklage as Bolivar Trask Shawn Ashmore as BobbyDrake/Iceman Omar Sy as Bishop Evan Peters as Peter Maximoff/Quicksilver Daniel Cudmore as Colossus Fan Bingbing as Blink Adan Canto as Sunspot Booboo Stewart as James Proudstar/Warpath Josh Helman as Major William StrykerAll of these are beyond Masterful decision making brought to by our Director Bryan Singer.Being a sequel to X-Men: First Class, fixing the continuity errors, having only X-Men: First Class and X-Men: Days of Future Past in the time-line, having a cohesive setup and exploring more of The X-Men Franchise, The moments were Quicksilver was on screen, the sentinels, visuals/effects, sound-track, and last of all: Leading us to X-Men: Apocalypse.N Cons': Bone Claws, taking Quicksilver out of the movie way too soon, never bringing Quicksilver back during the rest of the movie, no repercussions after Quicksilver left, Quicksilver never acknowledging Magneto is hid Father, and the lazy post-credit tease.The Cast: if you've seen the first half of this review when I went over this movies Pros' then you've seen the entire movie's cast so whats the point of rehashing the exact same thing??The Director: Bryan SingerProducers: Fox StudiosBudget: X-Men: Days of Future Past had an estimate budget of 40,000,000$ Dollars.Acclaim: Very Positive Critical acclaim from: General Audiences, Fan of The X-Men Franchise, Comic Book Fans, and Critics.Box Office Earnings: X-Men: Days of Future Past Made a total of Worldwide $746,039,152 Dollars.Rating: One of The Greatest Movie of All Times!

reviews.review_title: amazing movie – a blockbuster action packed movie
reviews.content: In 2014 there are many marvel movies released but this was best. Bryan Singer returns and made best X-Men movie after being absent for the past four films, and what a return he has made. 'Days of Future Past' is truly an impressive and spectacular installment in both the 'X- Men' franchise and the entire Marvel Cinematic Universe, combining the casts from both the original trilogy and the prequel allowing the audience to view the 'X- Men' in the past, present and future. The action scenes are intense and spectacularly choreographed with some fantastic heroes and foes fighting both against and alongside each other. As a personal opinion, 'Days of Future Past' is the best film to have graced the Marvel film franchise and one of the greatest superhero films of all-time. A visually stunning and exhilarating flick that combines the best elements of the series to create a fantastic and entertaining film. The story was amazing but i was disappointed by 3d effects.
I just really didn't understand how Charles came back to life in the first place???

reviews.review_title: One of the Best X-Men Movies, But Overwhelming...
reviews.content: X-Men: Days of Future Past is probably is the perfect movie for all the fans of the comics and the movies, but if you don't know much you'll either be lost sometimes or just start fresh with this movie -and I am one of the those who got lost, even though I have some previous knowledge from the franchise- because a lot happens, and changes everything from some of the previous X-Men movies. Therefore, my only problem with the movie was that everything happened so fast, that it almost felt as if nothing had happened. And that to me felt like a problem, because after the movie ended I still was trying to figure out what had happened and how it all affected and changed the timeline from the previous X-Men Movies. Also, I was trying to put the pieces together, but after I did some research and reading, it appears that there wasn't much to notice just that everything was back to normal, and maybe it was just me that felt like I had to pay extreme attention to every detail. Thus, I really liked all the action -which was a lot- and all the visual effects, which personally weren't as great as I hoped for, but for the most part they were really good. Moreover, the acting was also very good, and even though I enjoyed more watching all the originals X-Men instead of the ones from the First Class, which sadly weren't that much on-screen, it was still pretty cool to see both timelines intersect and happen subsequently. That being said, because there was too many characters sometimes it felt like there wasn't enough focus on some of them (Original X-Men members), because it felt like everything happened around the Wolverine and everyone else took second and third place. [**SPOILERS AHEAD**] And so, I would like to mention that the last sequence where everything is back to normal was what I was waiting for all this time, and just to see everything back to normal and everyone together felt right and just they way it should stay, and hopefully continue from there instead and continuing with the past and their younger-selfs. There is a scene after the end of all the credits which shows the future villain of the sequel X-Men: Apocalypse. Although it may be a brief one, it's quite interesting and different.

reviews.review_title: Days of future past can't pass fast enough!
reviews.content: X-Men Days of Future Past is yet another failed adaptation of one of the most successful comic book franchises of all time. Those of us who grew up with X-Men have come to love the characters and their back stories. The most beloved mutants, Storm, Kitty Pryde, and Rogue, who have been a constant from the beginning have had much of their character and presence stripped away and replaced with male characters such as Magneto, Beast, and Wolverine who have dominated the big screen script. A lot of focus was placed on Mystique as well. Their sleek comic book costumes have been replaced by black militant riot gear, which looks a lot like Batman's rubber suit. X-Men 1-2 and 3 story lines centered around Wolverine, and the male characters. It appears to me that the writers and the directors are intimidated by strong powerful woman, and I'm left with the impression that they didn't even research the mutants individual back stories. The most disappointing scenes is when Storm, Cyclops, and Gene Gray, where all being tossed around by Toad...really? Based on the comic book character, Storm is a strong willed leader who commands the group and takes down the difficult villains. However, on the big screen she's portrayed as a timid mutant who take orders from Wolverine, and poor Rogue was slowly erased completely. The writers and directors missed a great opportunity to explore the full potential of the most powerful and diverse mutants of the X-Men franchise. I would like to have seen more impending doom with a lot more of power display and fight scenes from Storm, and Rogue, and a lot less of Wolverine saving the day. I do not like any of the existing X-Men movies. My wish is that I live long enough to see X-Men rebooted about 10 years from now with directors and writers who appreciate the original vision of X-Men without dumbing down any of the characters.

I would still say First Class or X2 is the best X-Men movie, but DOFP is probably the most intense X-Men to date. I also would've preferred a total reboot instead of attempting to have any sort of cohesive storyline with the original movies due to X3's debacle, but they managed to make it work. Having said all this, the time traveling element was believable and the acting is top notch. There are always some inconsistencies with what powers each individual mutant posses and how they deviate from the comic book (e.g. Shadowcat, Mystique) but they didn't bother me that much. My only suggestion would've been to give the Sentinels a more prominent role in the 1970s storyline. Not only would it have been cool to see more Sentinels, it would explain how certain events in the 1970s could've occurred.

i think it'll a good movie, the x-men is an interesting story because the theme in the movie have so much drama, action an others factors that attract the attention of the people with out a scary excluding special effects. the x-men's movies are attractive and any can see any of its movies and not get bored. if i'm changing the channels and accidentally i find a x-men's movie, i leave the channel because i really like these movies, i can see 100 times the same movie and i don't get bored. i like the wolverine history, it's why act like it is. i want to this movie will be spectacular, I'm waiting for that, the new history have a different course, with this stuff from the past, to continue the line of clearing movie, it's important, because if you want to understand an series or movie you need to know the past and events happened before the movie, when you have enough information about something you understand all about that and you can do own opinion. i'm expecting a lot of this movie. i hope it's cool.

X-men: Days of Future Past 70This was movie was good action and all don't get me wrong on that, but I just don't see how everyone thinks this movie is groundbreaking. It's not like we have not ever seen any of this before. And also the time travel idea probably had so many holes in it that you can't even count them all. They seemed desperate to bring all the characters from both time periods in together in one epic duel. But, I guess that it did work out good, and it was something to witness the time period clashes. The ending was okay and good and all, but to me, I just don't see how that would have been possible. Everybody's back alive, and they lived happily ever after, oh but there's going to be another problem that will surface. Whatever. Good summer, action flick with good characters.

reviews.review_title: An incredible spectacle. Hard to knock
reviews.content: This was an incredible film. Multi-faceted, multi-layered, but in no way difficult to follow. The future scenes were the best action scenes I think I've ever seen and they weren't blurred like the bloody Transformers films. You could see what was happening. The acting was very earnest and sincere. I actually felt like these characters meant a lot to each other and what they were doing was real. James MacAvoy (someone please tell Leonardo DiCaprisun to watch James MacAvoy act so he can see how it's really done) was excellent in the tortured role. Michael Fassbender was so fantastically intimidating. For the first time, I actually enjoyed Jennifer Lawrence in a film (and I really enjoyed watching her in this role). I loved seeing Bishop finally. I can't see that complete cardboard cut-out of an actor, Aaron Taylor- Johnson, doing as good a performance of Quicksilver as the young lad here. Toad was believable thankfully. Hugh Jackman did his usual great portrayal of Wolverine. Ellen Page- we really need to see more of Ellen Page. She's a brilliant actress. The 'Sirs' McKellen and Stewart were just fantastic to watch. Halle Berry was enjoyable. I found it difficult watching Colossus get his arse kicked, but the Sentinels were just a magnificent foe. Hard to put any other antagonists above them. they reminded me of the T-1000 from Terminator 2. They were just an completely irresistible force.So, in conclusion, plus sides: The Sentinels Trask Both Magnetos Mystique Both Professor Xs Bishop The portal woman (loved her and I loved the way it made me think of the game 'Portal') The action scenes The storyline (which I really thought was so well thought out) The future scenes Quicksilver Not sure if it was Pyro or The Human Torch, but he was good anyway Even the Iceman was good. The humour was good. I laughed a few times. The film basically kept me smiling throughout (apart from when it was shocking me with revelations and some of the things that happen to my favourite characters)8/10A very high '8/10'8.9/10One thing I've noticed in myself as I've reflected on the film is just how tortured Wolverine is. This is the first time I've actually seen the character as such a damaged individual. There is a scene between Prof X and Wolverine, which I originally thought was a little lame (not too lame, but just quite sensitive). But then, when I thought back to the whole film all the way to the end, I actually feel very sorry for the guy. He's like a human guinea pig. Because his body heals, he feel duty- bound, obligated to allow himself to be use for all kinds of destructive procedures. One thing that doesn't regenerate are his emotions. It's almost as though he's saying "You can't hurt me. I can take it. I can take anything." But he can't. Not in his mind. If you're reading this review and you haven't watched the film- watch it at your first opportunity.

reviews.review_title: Best action movie of the year!
reviews.content: From start to finish this movie is engaging, entertaining,and exciting. The plot is simple and easy to understand; something that is lacking from many modern movies. The present is in chaos because Mystique's power is used for military purposes. In order to fix this the wolverine must go to the 1970's. He cant do it alone, so he must get the help of x-men characters from the time. This is the factor that makes the movie so entertaining, it's interesting to see them interact when they where young. It's definitely without doubt the best x-men movie and one of the most creative movies in a while. This is coming from a non x men fan so its easy to say that almost any action-movie fan can enjoy this movie. I highly recommend it.

The original DOFP story was originally a two issue comic back in 1980, however it feels like it was dreamed up especially to solve the problem the studio faced after 2011's X-Men: First Class: what to do with a franchise that has been split into two time lines with two sprawling casts – the originals (Patrick Stewart, Ian McKellan etc.) and the younger iterations (James Mcavoy, Michael Fassbender et all.) DOFP begins in 2023 with a voice-over from Professor X as he explains mutants are on the verge of extinction and asks "is our future truly set?" This is followed by a fantastic action sequence involving characters both old (Magneto, Storm, Colossus, Wolverine) and new (Blink, Bishop, Warpath) against a mass of unstoppable Sentinel robots that have been created specifically to destroy mutants. It is simply a breathtaking display of action cinema. The only way, it seems, to prevent mutant extinction is to send Wolverine back in time to his 1973 body to prevent the war before it begins. Charged with stopping Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence) from assassinating weapons-maker Bolivar Trask (Peter Dinklage) – the event which will result in global annihilation, Wolverine is hampered by obstacles – his claws are no longer metal, Professor X is a depressive alcoholic without his powers and he also has to seek the help of Magneto who is being held captive in an unbreakable plastic prison beneath the Pentagon. This is undoubtedly one of the highlights of DOFP as speedster Quicksilver is recruited to assist the team in the breakout. The film slows down half way as it develops the characters but focuses specifically on the relationships between Professor X, Magneto and Mystique and their quest to prevent the doom that lay before them and all the "What Ifs" that are presented. With time travel films there are always questions that don't get answered thoroughly but it's a fresh idea that both past and future time lines are allowed to coincide at the same time. The original characters are utilized well in the future setting and the new characters are blended in seamlessly with the story. The music is excellent and the special effects are superb - Singer has put every cent of his $250m on screen for the audience to enjoy.In short DOFP is far more sophisticated and has the best and most complex story of any X-Men movie to date. Be sure to stay until after the credits for a glimpse of 2016's sequel X-Men: Apocalypse. X well and truly marks the spot!

With X-Men – Days of Future Past, director Bryan Singer makes a welcome return to the mutant universe. He had helmed the first two films but jumped ship on the third one, directing the morose Superman Returns instead. Brett Ratner took the helm for X-Men: Last Stand and almost sank the franchise with a rambling mess of a movie, which badly flubbed the classic Dark Phoenix storyline from the comics. Trying to salvage the franchise, the next movie (X-Men: First Class) jumped back in time to tell an origin story, with not too much regard for continuity with the trilogy it followed. X-Men – DoFP forms a bridge between First Class and the trilogy by way of time travel, and is based on another iconic story from the comics. In the movie version, Wolverine's consciousness is sent back into the past, into his younger body, to prevent an assassination that will lead to an all-out, devastating war between humans and mutants. To effect this, he will have to convince Xavier and Magneto to make nice with each other.X-Men – DoFP again plays fast and loose with continuity, ignoring most of what happened in The Last Stand, but oddly not all. If you saw the scene from the end credits of The Wolverine, or simply saw the trailers for X-Men – DoFP, you may have been wondering how how Magneto got his powers back and how Xavier is alive. Well, keep wondering, as the movie does not explain either of these things. Admittedly, The Last Stand hinted at both developments with its final shot and the end credits sequence respectively, but it feels like a pertinent part of the story was skipped. Not that I can see how it could have been squeezed into this outing, apart from just blurting out one or two lines of exposition. X-Men – DoFP is already longish and focused on other things. In any case, most people – myself included – will be happy that X-Men – DoFP clearly gives its blessing to people pretending that The Last Stand never happened, or was an alternate universe, or whatever. Messing around with time travel, has now given future X-Men films leeway to pick and choose with regards to continuity. Just show Wolverine raising an eyebrow and have him go 'Hey, that's not how it happened!' and you're in the clear.But aside from all that – is X-Men – DoFP any good? Yup, quite. I know it plays fast and loose with its comic book source material, but the cast is engaging, the action sequences are spectacular and the plot is a fine piece of hokum. There is a good balance between character moments and action, though the movie stuffs in a bunch of mutants who get cool fights, but are given no personality to speak of. If you've read the comics, you can project depth onto them, but they will be intriguing but flat if haven't done your nerdy research. Most of the focus is on the cast from First Class, but there are some surprising cameos from the 'original' cast.The most interesting 'new' character is Quicksilver (Evan Peters) a kleptomaniac speedster. Those in the know, know he is – in fact – Magneto's son, but though the movie drops a cheeky line of dialogue hinting at this, that's all you'll hear about it. People were all ready to hate this incarnation of the character when pictures surfaced with him in an awful, silvery costume. And it is indeed a horrible costume, but one that is only on-screen for a very short amount of time. There is a scene in which Quicksilver takes out a room full of guards – seen from his superfast perspective – that will make you want to cheer, and Peters makes him charming and cocky. It's a shame he doesn't hang around for longer. The next Avengers movie (Age of Ultron, due 2015) will also feature a version of this character, as Quicksilver – confusingly – is both part of the mutant universe (movie rights held by Fox) and the Avengers universe (movie rights held by Marvel, but any mention of mutants is iffy). Another blow to continuity, but *shrug*.Despite having a good time with the movie, I was scratching my head at the grand finale. Though changes were made to the original timeline, it seems that what happened instead wouldn't exactly have made things better for mutants in the long run. Except that it apparently did. And who am I to argue with the vagueries of cause and effect? As long as I can purge The Last Stand from my mind completely, it's all good. @PopCultJunk

I found this movie to be one of the best X Men movies they have done so far. I was one of the people who watch the cartoons. In the cartoon episodes they did an actual series on the Sentinels. And it was quite good. So to actually see a live action movie with a good plot and followed pretty much the same theme was a delight. I guess the thing I'm most happy about is the plot was really good it wasn't aimless and far- reaching. The characters were developed and played out there roll just as we do in real life. I was always told by my brother a comic book fan that really and truly the X Men were a soap opera for people who don't actually like to watch the ones on TV. But I would say I like this movie so much I would watch it again. I really wish what they did with this movie they had done in the beginning with Jean and did the Phoenix series. But alas they didn't and at least this was well done. I've always liked Mystique and thought they developed her character quite well for a change. If you read her history in Marvel she is definitely more than meets the eye. Glad to see they finally got it right I would tell any comic book fan to go see it.

You may underestimate this entry even if you overestimate it. Emotionally, the story, actors and scenes take you to a place you never thought it could go. Whether fan-boy or average movie goer the new X-men with Bryan Singer back at the helm keeps you guessing with all your favorite mutants once again like you've never seen them. Hugh Jackman, who seems to be the face of the X-men delivers as always with his dry sense of humor. Jennifer Lawrence is more a focus in this one which makes sense. However James MaCavoy steals the show as the one and only Professor Charles Xavier with a great performance you'll never see coming. Not to exclude the rest of the cast, this rivals The Dark Knight franchise with a thriller like mentality that you won't wanna miss on the big screen.

There is nothing spectacular about this movie. The best part was the beginning, where they were in the future fighting the Sentinels. The action was raw and realistic and the CGI was amazing.However, once they traveled back in time, things got a bit boring. I just feel like some of these guys are not very good actors or don't go very deep into their characters.I love Hugh Jackman, but he has no passion as the Wolverine anymore. Overall, I was disappointed with this movie. It started off on a very high note but got real boring.2 Things I wanna point out.1. One of the Coolest scenes was when Quicksilver disarms all of those bodyguards2. Why the hell did Magneto bring an entire stadium to surround the White House when the President is hiding in a Bunker underground? LMAO! Makes NO SENSE!!!!

Before i start my review i would first like to tell you that i am proudly a long time fan of the Marvel universe and deep lover of the comic book universes it has created. When i watched the original trilogy i enjoyed them but was disappointed feeling they lacked a certain something, and after the devastation of the disaster that was 'The last stand' i had thought it would be a long time before professor Xavier and his X-men returned. Thank the universe i was wrong.When First class hit the cinemas it was like a breath of fresh air had revitalized the stagnant body of the franchise, everything i had wanted it to be it was. We were shown superb acting and cinematography, a beautifully written plot and there was a constant sense of energy and drive. And most of all it made me think and reflect and lose myself in my imagination and thoughts. First class had me pining for more.So it was that i saw 'Days of future past' as soon as it was in my local cinema. I don't know where any of the two hours and ten minutes went, i was hooked from start to finish and so engrossed that time sped past. 'Days of future past' takes us on a tremendous journey from the bleak reaches of the future back into the past. We see X-men from both the old and new franchises face their toughest battles and some of their most defining moments. The wonderfully crafted script makes for a seamless smooth ride despite the cuts between past and present and even gives tasty titbits in a nod to other x-men story lines. The characters are better than ever and the sheer acting power behind them drives them forward to greater heights. I must in particular tip my hat to James Mcavoy and Jennifer Lawrence. Despite the dark brooding storyline which X-men fans will already have an idea of there is still plenty of laughs to be had. A certain scene with speedster Quicksilver is in my opinion the funniest and coolest scene in all X-men films. A nod to young peter evans who we will be seeing more of in the next film i am certain.Without giving away too much you can be assured that 'Days of future past' will have you ensnared in your seat, leave you stunned, laughing and maybe even have you deep in thought by the end. If that's not enough to convince you of this films brilliance than i shall say but one last thing, All wrongs of the past are righted, all things become full circle.

Second worst comic book movie of 2014, just barely beating out Amazing Spiderman 2. Another lousy Bryan Singer adaptation that turns something otherworldly and exciting into a dull forgettable mess with whiny or bland characters, not to mention Singer's typical mishandling of characters such as showing 1 minute cameos of fan boy favorite mutants(which for some reason is excessively praise as being perfectly represented and gets the majority of nerds wet in their pants) and giving ample screen time to spotlight stealer yet least interesting character Wolverine(reminding us once again this is Not the X-Men Cinematic Universe but the Wolverine Cinematic Universe).Are we still stuck in the late 90s/early 2000s era of lame black leather costumes? Haven't Marvel themselves proof that heroes can have color in their outfits and not look ridiculous in live action. Even the last X-Men film proves that colorful costumes can work. OK,enough of the costumes lets focus on the plot which is just a rehash of an earlier film plot which was done a Decade Earlier. Plot:X-Men need to stop a threat by some evil humans and for some reason Magneto is there to help, but in a twist you saw coming from a mile away,good old Mags back stabs the X-Men and causes even worse crap to happen and once again Prof.X forgives Mags at the end after all the stuff he pulled because Hope Lol Hope(Yeah....keep telling yourself that,Prof.Chum). Now either this is the plot of Dofp or the plot of X men 2(alright maybe not that last bit but you get my point). In between this recycled premise, we have scenes of Prof.X being a whiny bum throughout most of his screen time, Jennifer Lawrence clearly phoning in her performance,Magneto being a 1 dimensional Mcu villain and Ellen Page constantly tearing up. I will say the effect are really good but the lighting quality is completely awful,while not nearly as bad as The Avengers, the entire flick looked almost like it was made for television.Whoa,I didn't expect to write this much about this turkey but here we are. I wouldn't recommend this turd to anyone but if you're still nostalgic for that time-long era of black leather fetish superhero flicks then go for it.

I really enjoyed watching the movie. It had it all, if you ask me. I mean; seriously, it was emotional, exciting and the visual effects were amazing. I was expecting a lot from this movie because I used to watch X-men cartoons and the Days of Future Past episodes were the best ones and the cast is amazing and we all know what Bryan Singer is capable to do.The Quicksilver character was surprisingly successful. And I have really no words for James McAvoy and Jennifer Lawrence, I just hope to see them more in good movies like this.It is the second best movie based on a comic(Dark Knight is first) and the best X-Men movie.9.5/10

I found this installment of the X-Men entertaining and enjoyed the story. I watched X2 recently and noticed the Nightcrawler opening was similar to the Quicksilver scene. I did enjoy both scenes but couldn't help think that the Quicksilver scene was an extended version of the Nightcrawler scene from X2. I'm looking forward to the next installment, Apocalypse. Wasn't too excited about the future Sentinels design, it looked way too CG so I'm hoping the next movie will incorporate more practical FX.So far in the X-Men series, I enjoyed Mangold's The Wolverine and X2 the most.

Since their arrival on the comic book scene in 1963, The X-Men have been always been Marvel's most famous ragtag crew. From comics to cartoons and movies, these characters and their world have continued to not only exist, but grow and expand. The newest film from director Bryan Singer, X-men: Days Of Future Past, takes the world created in the first X-Men films and skillfully blends them together in a time-bending, fun and action packed adventure.In 2023, mutants are being brutally hunted and killed by ruthless robot beings called Sentinels. Professor Xavier (Patrick Stewart) and his on- again, off-again best friend Magneto (Ian McKellen) enlist the angry but lovable brute Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) to travel back in time. His mission is to try and reverse a deed done in 1973 by the shape shifter Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence) whose actions lead to the creation of the Sentinels. Once Wolverine is back in time he must bring together the estranged younger Magneto (Michael Fassbender) and Xavier (James McAvoy) so they find Mystique and stop this future from happening.Singer, who directed both X-Men and X2: X-Men United, delivers the best X-Men film so far. The task to bring all these story lines together from every movie in the X-Men arsenal seems impossible and improbable. Singers success is impressive as one would expect nothing but an incoherent mess full of missed plot cues and poorly written character choices. He even gives importance and the right amount of attention to the characters who aren't considered part of the main line-up. Mutants such as Blink, Warpath, Bishop, Sunspot and Havok are all given short, yet important moments to shine that work well within the story.Jackman, Fassbender and McAvoy form a fun and angsty team in 1973. The three actors use their amazing talents to fill their roles to the brim, bringing honesty, sadness, and humor to each of their characters. Lawrence (Winter's Bone, American Hustle) once again shines as Mystique,who has matured since X-Men: First Class. She gives Mystique aimlessness while showing her pure passion for her self appointed mission to protect mutants from evil humans like Bolivar Trask (Peter Dinklage), who have no sympathy for mutants and only see them as a threat to humankind.A stand out in the film is Even Peters as a young Quicksilver. Quicksilver has the power to move very fast and one of the most entertaining and memorable sequences in the film is when you are shown what he can truly do. This sequence will be remembered not only for this movie, but in years to come. The use of special effects might ensure Quicksilver of The X-Men will be more beloved than the soon-to-be-met Quicksilver in Avengers: Age of Ultron.X-Men: Days of Future Past is not only the perfect summer blockbuster, it is also the perfect superhero film. Mixing the familiarity for the characters with the time bending storyline you are given a fun ride with a social message of acceptance of people everywhere, which is what X-Men is always and should always be about: equality for all. It's an important message that needs to be heard and it always helps to use sexy mutants and lovable classic anti-heroes to tell it.

reviews.review_title: excellent storytelling, thorough performance, and powerful finish
reviews.content: The movie was so good and so memorable. I don't even know where to begin but simply I must commend Brian Singer for his maturity and growth in developing a powerful, cohesive and compelling movie for the ages. I have to say this was the best superhero movie I've seen so far and actually the most memorable movie I've seen in recent years. I want to share so much but don't want to spill spoilers onto this review. It's just really good from start to finish. But that ending was so powerful and engaging. I just love the extreme Brian Singer went to make the audience engage very deeply with the mutants especially in the way they faced an immovable enemy - the sentinels. As an audience, I was so deeply engaged with the mutants that there actually was a sigh of relief when there future was altered for good. It's more than just a good guys vs bad but the hinge of the movie came at realizing the climax of the power of choice and wondering what each individual would do with that choice but especially for the two well-known villains - Mystique and Magneto. Striking movie and a stellar performance from every character. That kitchen scene was just superb. Made the entire theater laugh out loud. Bravo.

reviews.review_title: Exceptional adventure film--the biggest and best of the series
reviews.content: Combining the classic cast of the first three films, with that of First Class, and adding in new faces, this seventh film chronicling Marvel's mutants is easily the most ambitious. To handle this time-traveling extravaganza, Bryan Singer returned to the director's chair and provides a movie that never gets lost in its own conceit.Singer's biggest strength is his ability to place comic heroes into our reality, with the film covering real world threats that move beyond the mutant microcosm. The film is also visually stunning with the Nimrod Sentinels battles, as well as the instantly iconic Quicksilver sequence, viewers are treated to some of the strongest action in this franchise. The film also does an outstanding job balancing the cast, and while Wolverine is still central, Magneto, Professor X, and most especially Mystique fully share the spotlight.

reviews.review_title: X-Men DOFP Unites the Series Together
reviews.content: X-Men: DOFP had a tough task of expanding the X-men universe, combining the old series, with the new, and had to convincingly explain away some of the series continuity errors, with a complex time travel plot. This could've equaled a recipe for disaster, but instead this latest X-Men film mostly succeeds. In fact it succeeds not only as a sequel that ties the two (originally) separate series together, but also manages to fix some of the things that X-Men: The Last Stand handled poorly.X-Men: DOFP is first and, foremost a great sequel, that is action packed, with enough emotion, and humor, that makes it arguably the best X-Men film thus far. This is because these characters have been setup in multiple prior films, so that by the time this film comes along, we get to see some of these characters, and their arcs, become fully realized. The film focuses mainly on Xavier/Charles, Magneto/Erik, Mystique/Raven, Wolverine/Logan, and to some extent Beast/Hank. There are many brief moments of other mutants, who get their moment to shine as well. Most notably is a new mutant named Peter Maximoff aka Quicksilver, who steals every moment of screen time he gets. The prison break scene with Quicksilver, is one of the best scenes in a comic book film, while both comical, and visually brilliant. The point of this film is to change the future by altering the past. The film starts off in a post apocalyptic future, where both mutants, and humans have been nearly wiped out by Terminator-like robots called Sentinels.Wolverine is sent back in time to the year 1973, where he must find a younger Charles Xavier, and Magneto, to help stop Mystique from killing a man named Bolivar Trask. Trask is the creator of the Sentinels, and his murder sets things in motion that will lead to the eventual demise of mutants, and humans alike. None of this film's main characters in the past are at their best, and need a push to be a better version of themselves, and it's up to Wolverine to be patient, and help them along, in order to change the course of time, which as Logan states "Patience isn't my strongest suit". The tale is a bleak one, but never devoid of humor, which makes the film fun, but also helps keeps it's characters feeling genuine. Thats the best strength DOFP has, you care about whats going on, and wan't to see these characters that are beloved fans, make it out of this alive.As mentioned above, this movie does "fix" some of the continuity problems the series had, and also resurrects a few characters, that were lost to soon. The ending of the film really pays off, and left me very happy, not just because of seeing old characters back, but because everything up to that point was compelling, and emotionally resonate. I would highly recommend this film to anyone who's a fan of the series, or is just a fan of good storytelling, and interesting characters. There's a couple minor pacing issues here, and there, and some may argue certain characters don't get enough screen time, but overall X-Men: DOFP delivers, and is a fantastic return to the X-men series old, and new.

I discovered the X-Men's there some years ago. I really took a lot of fun watching them. Loved identify with the character of Hugh Jackman, Wolvorine / (Logan). It seemed perfectly normal to be attracted to this version out on the big screen. At the first opportunity we have to see the movie in theaters. With new technology, the special effects we are impressed. And the image of the first movies we have not been disappointed. This is a film completely amazing science fiction. It would have been a shame not to see him on the big screen. But still I advise you to watch the entire series, doing a marathon day, one behind the other, good plan for the long winter day

reviews.review_title: Brett Ratner's damage has been undone
reviews.content: Like others have said, I think everyone is struggling to find something wrong with the film. With the future being changed, it also changed the past. Jean Grey returns, and she never killed Scott, was killed by Wolverine. Any of the damage Brett Ratner caused in Last Stand seems to have gone after this.Quicksilver was hilarious (but slightly annoying), and Blink's teleport portals were really cool, and I particularly liked the slingshot of Colossus in a Portal style.I was disappointed not to see more than the one scene (showed most of it in the end credit scene of Captain America: The Winter Soldier) of Havoc (Alex Summers). I don't know why Anna Pacquin was in the credits, she had a 5 second non-speaking role at the very end of the film, mainly just to show she was alive. Also some people in the cinema were asking how Xavier was alive. It is explained in the comics, and we know it happens in the film because of the end credit scene in Last Stand, but it is never explained in this film, which I was surprised by. Plus, I did notice when James McAvoy's Xavier was looking into Wolverine's mind, it would swap from 1 finger on Wolverine's temple to two between shots. Happened multiple times. But again, this is all nitpicking.Absolutely brilliant film, really enjoyable to watch.What we are left questioning? What the hell was that end credit scene? Where will they go from here? Something that bothered me from the trailer: if Xavier transferred himself into his brain dead twin brother's body, why was he still in a wheelchair if his brother never got shot on the beach like he did?

I'm going to keep this brief. Saw this film last night and it kept me on the edge of my seat for the whole 2 hours and eleven minutes. Superb action mixed with great story telling.Recommend 100% if you like any sort of comic book film - this wipes the floor with the other X- men films. Suitable for families and adults, keeps you engaged throughout. There's no point me mentioning any part of the storyline, so just watch it. oh and Jennifer Lawrence is gorgeous in this, as usual. See you.Peace.

reviews.review_title: Yessss. Finally a good X-men in 11 years.
reviews.content: Wow. Just wow. This film really surprised me as it combines both the old cast with the new cast. The film has a good way of showing us what has happend to the world since X-men the last stand and the wolverine which came out the year before this did. The plot is the world is overrun by robots called the sentinels which were created by Boliver Trask in the 70s but before that he was killed by mystique. The X-men have spread out over the globe and stick together in order to survive. The X-men decide to send wolverine back to the 70s to stop mystique from killing Boliver Trask. But in order to stop her he needs the help of Charles Xavier in the 70s but he isn't in a wheelchair he's walking using drugs but the drugs make his powers go. Wolverine succeeds but also needs the help of magneto but he's in prison cause he accidentally made the bullet curved which killed JFK. But in order to break him out they use quicksilver to break him out. They work together and they manage to stop mystique but also reveal to the whole world that mutants exist. The movie as whole works together so well. But the best thing about it is that the previous films don't exist in the X-men universe as they are now wiped out. So that means no more X-men last stand and no more X-men Origins wolverine

The previous films have all been lacking something, maybe with the exception of X2, but Days of Future Past renews the series in a great way. The acting in the film knocks the ball out of the park, by bringing the new mutants together with the old mutants to create great chemistry between most of the cast. Every actor has a time to shine, even if it may be for 2-3 minutes, but they all make an impact on the film. Hugh Jackman, probably makes the best out of Wolverine,by bringing out his inner animal within the film, unlike most of the other X-Men films.The action is also much better handled in the film than the others as well, like the fights between the Sentinels and Past Magneto. The CGI effects are great, but the only downside in the film are the potholes, which are usually fixed in many ways though. Definitely see this film if you are looking for a fun, action packed film. It's probably the best way to start of the summer film season in my own opinion.

X-Men: Days of Future Past. Can you guess what it's about from the title? You got it. It's the X-Men involved in time travelling adventures. No, it's not lame. This movie kicks butt. I could wrap this review up in one sentence by saying if you liked 'X-Men: First Class' you'll love this. I could, but then it wouldn't be the most in depth review ever.Firstly, and I say this with an unblemished record of staunch heterosexuality, Hugh Jackman's buttocks are sublime. That's right ladies (and men if you're so inclined), if you're a Jackman fan, rejoice! You get to see the macho, mutton-chopped mutant in all his glory in the film's opening scenes and it is impressive. The guy's body has been carved out of some form of naturally occurring rock-like substance. Most likely a rock.Jackman gives his usual dependable performance as the fan favourite mutant. In his 7th outing as the gruff, tri-clawed wise-cracker he's in fine form. It's no insult, however, to say that he is well and truly outshone by some of his peers. This is quite possibly the best ensemble cast I've ever seen in a super-hero movie. And they all deliver. Jennifer Lawrence is exquisite as the blue-skinned mimic 'Mystique'. As she cavorts around the screen she provides ample depth to the character's inner conflict, and ample perve time to the superficial among us. She is definitely the hottest blue chick ever on screen (sorry Smurfette and Avatar girl).Peter Dinklage, better known as Tyrion Lannister from 'Game of Thones' is, as expected, excellent. Indeed, he is becoming such an accomplished performer that his 'dwarfism' (is that politically correct?) is hardly noticed. His performances in general ensure that he is a giant on screen. His portrayal here of Doctor Bolivar Trask, the scientist responsible for creating the sentinels who will all but eradicate the mutants, is no exception.Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellen are as solid as ever in their portrayals of Charles Xavier (Professor X) and Erik Lehnsherr (Magneto). Their screen time, set in the war ravaged future, is relatively small compared to that of their younger 1970's selves: James McAvoy (Xavier) and Michael Fassbender (Lehnsherr). And justifiably so, since the majority of the action takes place in the flared pant, big haired setting of 1973. As the two leaders of the younger brigade of mutants they are excellent. Fassbender, in particular, is in fine form as the tortured, metal controlling Magneto. His on-screen presence and charisma is such that he propels Magneto into rare company with the greatest ever on screen villains. Although, it can be hard identifying him as a villain, when it's so easy to relate to his motives.Fans of the comics will be delighted to know that the super fast Quicksilver makes his big screen debut and just about steals the show in one memorable scene. Seriously, his 10 minutes or so is worth the price of admission alone. He is awesomeness personified.The action sequences are breath-taking, as expected. I only saw it in 2- D, but I imagine it would be spectacular in 3-D. The writing is fantastic. There are several laugh out loud moments, which is rare in a super-hero movie where persecution and genocide are the central themes. I guess, if you really tried, you could find problems with the theories of time travel and the consequences of jumping back 5 decades to stop an assassination from ever occurring. I, however, chose not to watch with a copy of Stephen Hawking's 'Brief History of Time' in hand ready to disprove the films treatment of time travel. Really, you're watching a movie about mutants with super heroes, surely it's easier just to accept that this IS happening!!Possibly the most pleasing aspect is that director Bryan Singer, responsible for the original X-Men and X2 movies, has managed to tie everything together nicely and undo the wrongs of Brett Ratner from X- Men 3 (The last stand). In case you've forgotten, that was something of a let down. And Rattner pretty much decided it would be a good idea to kill off half the cast. Without giving too much away, Singer sorts it out in this instalment, with what is pretty much a giant "f#*k you" to that butcher Rattner.In summary, see this movie. It will not disappoint.X-Men: Days of Future Past 8.5/10 reviewed by Matt French https://www.facebook.com/shenaniganmoviereviews

Great story line and action. . . BUT what's up with the F bomb language? Did it add to the plot or action? NO, not at all – it really does need to be in the movie. Marvel movies don't need it and Families do not want to hear it. If it's a Marvel movie, which essentially a comic book movie, I am bringing my kids to the movie. I don't need to be hit with F bombs and butts. It doesn't add "jack" to the movie. Thanks, but no thanks. Hollywood wake up. Keep the F bomb language and Hugh Jackmans butt off the screen.On a positive note, they did a great job of retro back to the 70's. The cars, the clothes and the music were a great 70's throw back. Great cast good story line. . . But the intro dragged a bit and really disappointed with the language.

reviews.review_title: X-Men: Honestly thought it was a great movie.
reviews.content: X-Men: Days of Future Past is probably the biggest, most action-packed superhero film yet, with all the X-Men and mutant villain from the past and future working together to obliterate mankind's threat: the Sentinels. Audiences recognize regular characters such as Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), Professor Xavier (Patrick Stewart), Magneto (Ian McKellen), Storm (Halle Berry), Shadowcat/Kitty Pryde (Ellen Page), Iceman (Shawn Ashmore), and Colossus (Daniel Cudmore). Jean Grey (Famke Janssen), Cyclops (James Marsden), and Rogue (Anna Paquin) had brief cameos. Characters from X-Men: First Class were also integrated into this film, including younger characters of Charles Xavier (James McAvoy), Magneto (Michael Fassbender), Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence), Beast (Nicholas Hoult), and Havoc (Lucas Till). One of the most captivating parts of X-Men: Days of Future Past was seeing the newest characters, including Bishop (Omar Sy)--who could absorb energy and reshoot it, Blink (Fan Bingbing)--who could teleport herself and other people with portals, Quicksilver (Evan Peters)--who could run at a superhuman speed, Sunspot (Adam Canto)--who is pyrokinetic, Warpath (Booboo Stewart)--who has superhuman reflexes, and Toad (Evan Jonikeit)--who has superhuman leaping abilities and a long, whip-like tongue. Bishop, Blink, Quicksilver, Sunspot, Warpath, and Toad fascinated watchers were their awesome abilities, displaying a lot of action, struggle, and power. Quicksilver's easiness of the fast life and his making time go slow for him provides comic relief as he fools around with the enemies ubiquitously. The mutants and X-Men of the future live in a desolate, dangerous world where they are always hunted for by the Sentinels, who have become extremely powerful and invincible over time. They make a desperate and extremely risky attempt to change history and prevent the war that dooms both humans and mutants by sending Wolverine back in time to prevent the Sentinel program from starting in the first place. Things don't go exactly well and straightforward, but with the burden of saving the world under Wolverine and the young mutants' backs, they make their best attempts to prove that they are not threats, some mutants going dangerous, violent paths. Fans of X-Men and Marvel comics will adore this movie and enjoy seeing all of their favorite but unseen characters on-screen, like watching Superman and Batman work together, except in a X-Men Marvel comics version. Little hints are sprinkled in that only fans will understand, such as that between Quicksilver and his father. X-Men: Days of Future Past resets everything that happened in the first X-Men movies and leads to the next movie, X-Men: Apocalypse, including an enigmatic post-credits scene.

Villainous arrogance coming back to bite itself on the ass!!! I suspect the X men villains have been a touch lazy in recent years, as "meek" and "ordinary" humans have worked tirelessly to prove the mighty X men villains aren't so superior after all. Good old human ingenuity created something more powerful than mutants, and guess what, the villainous mutants aren't so special anymore. And neither are the righteous mutants. And it seems that in an imaginary future that only mutants can see, the "ordinary" humans are yet again, their own worst enemy! Looking forward to X Men 6 - Extraordinary becomes Ordinary - when the whole planet decides they would like to be mutant!

reviews.review_title: So many plot holes you have to try not to think - at all
reviews.content: I liked the overall storyline, but this movie is nothing but one plot hole after another. To start with, Kitty has to constantly stand over Wolverine while she's projecting him back in time. But since he spends several days in the past, doesn't that mean she also has to stand there for several days? Wouldn't she at least have to have a bathroom break once and a while? Next, I'd like to know where Quicksilver got his Walkman from. Did he travel to the future, because this movie takes place in 1973 but Walkman's weren't invented until 1979? Now, as for Magneto, his power is to manipulate metal, right? So when he's standing on top of the train how does he know where to place the metal inside of it? Does he also have x-ray vision? And why do the robots obey his commands? Did he also reprogram them? Maybe he took computer programing classes while he was in prison - although that seems pretty unlikely considering most people didn't own a digital watch or even a pocket calculator back then. Finally, when Magneto orders the robots to kill the mutants, why don't they just immediately shoot him first? I mean he's standing right next to them, so shouldn't he be the first mutant they spot? Sorry but this movie has so many plot holes, the only way to enjoy it is to abandon all logic and just try not to think - at all.

reviews.review_title: My favorite X-Men movie to date.
reviews.content: I got into the X-Men franchise within the past year after seeing the teaser for this film. I really like the first two films by Bryan Singer, First Class is really good and I actually like Wolverine (2013). I didn't bother with Origins, and yes X3 was a piece of crap. But luckily, this movie makes up for that in so many ways. I still have yet to read an X-Men comic or watch an episode of any of the animated series, but I'd consider myself a fan of X-Men after watching these movies. The story as far as time travel is very reminiscent of Terminator with the sentinels search for humans and mutants in the future which fits in with the tone of the original trilogy and with the bright color palette in the past that ties into First Class and it also reminded me of Back to the Future with the fish out of water humor for Wolverine and of course with the ending where Logan wakes up to find that the future has changed for the better with Cyclops and Jean being alive. It might be too hard for some people to follow because of the multiple character, but each one gets their moment to shine. All thanks to Simon Kinberg's screenplay, the story doesn't feel packed as it seems at first glance. Singer also shows that he's more comfortable in his direction, out of respect to his previous movies, the scope of this film feels bigger and energetic than X 1 and 2. Even more than First Class I'd say. The drama and comedy have a nice blend together, the pacing is relentless but it doesn't forget to focus on the important things much like Dark Knight. And John Ottman's score is amazing, especially the opening theme. As I said, the characters each get their moment to shine and the actors deliver 100%. Hugh Jackman as Logan is great once again, and it's cool to see him as a more experienced Wolverine and is the one trying to help a younger Charles Xavier who at this point in his life has lost his way. And James MacAvoy gives probably the best performance out of the entire cast as we see Xavier learn how to hope again. Michael Fassbender is even more terrifying as Magneto than he was in First Class, and Jennifer Lawrence (my favorite actress) kicks ass as Mistyque. Nicolas Hoult, Patrick Stewart, Mckellan, Ashmore, Dinklage, Ellen Page, etc. are really good in their roles. And yes, Quicksilver is awesome. That scene in the Pentagon is priceless! I also like the central theme of hope particularly the hope Charles has for Magneto and Raven despite them getting their hands dirty.
