The writers really do an excellent job in maintaining order in a script which calls for two separate time lines and they perfectly executed balancing out enough of the past and present events to keep the suspense going and the punches flying.A breathtaking movie which reaches a broader audience than most might think. If you appreciate cinema and if you loved the first X-Men then GO SEE THIS FILM!

This movie is the thing that I reserve the word 'amazing' for.I loved the way that we were guided through the creative use of so many super-powers. The variety of powers exhibited was so much more than we are used to even from long running TV shows like Heroes and every single exhibition was executed imaginatively and brilliantly. They were able to do this by providing deep and meaningful explanation of why they were limiting the powers on screen. Instead of exploring one or two really powerful powers in the way that They thought were cool, they added and subtracted them without limiting things too much allowing for imagination of really complex interactions. The kind of explanation that gave you a basis for imagining this world. You are so immersed that you could stop focusing on just the vivid graphic image and are setup to try to predict what will happen next. When you believe you have a strategy for playing in this world is when they flip it on you and you are exposed to an even deeper plot or meaning and you're left with more mystery to apply what you know to, from earlier on in the movie and your experiences outside it.This movie mixes the dreams we have of super powers with the experience of playing strategy and combat games. One thing that particularly comes to mind is Blink's power, I've played hours of Valve's games Portal and Portal 2, playing challenges and designing my own, so I felt with her. I could see myself trying to play through these challenges, thinking on the fly, and I could feel the loss after every death. Among all the creativity shown through pretty pictures, cool mutations, and ability to stimulate the happiest parts of my imagination, This movie still found time to impact me more. The cut-scene after the credits changes the story entirely, it changes how we view history. The Egyptian pyramids, instead of being a symbol of how religion was able to bring a nation to enslave so many people to build their oppressive relic, to being a gift from a God showing the people what he is capable of so that he can help them. This bit of fantasy paints history in a much better light than I have ever been able to imagine. This pseudo-realistic version gives us hope for another explanation of the past, perhaps a more happy one. We are not locked in the ideas that we believe today.I can't add much more than, "I liked it a lot."

reviews.review_title: Recommended to fans and strangers alike.
reviews.content: Acting: Why is Patrick Stewart in this movie? First off, do I even have to comment on the alumni of this film? Hugh Jackman is Wolverine. Patrick Stewart is Professor X. Ian McKellen is Magneto. Got it? Okay. The acting in this film is solid for the most part. James McAvoy does a good job at portraying young Xavier as an intelligent and sympathetic character that, while not endowed with his future self's wisdom and virtue, doesn't succumb to the unbearable immaturity that we so often find with younger versions of characters. I'm aware that he was in First Class, but I never watched it. It honestly took a while for me to buy Michael Fassbender as Magneto, but he eventually settled right with me. I'm also aware that he was in First Class, but, like I said, I never watched it. Up next, and probably the one who stole the show, was Jennifer Lawrence as Mystique. Okay, Mystique was awesome in the cartoons, but that hasn't been so well represented as it is here. Mystique pretty much serves as the McGuffin of the film, which in turn puts more focus on Lawrence's performance. She's gorgeous, she's brutal, she's caring, she won't listen to what you have to say, she's vulnerable and she's deadly as. All of this and more is shown in her performance. I don't know what she's doing with that Hunger Games series, but she needs to be in more X-Men films. Does she personify Mystique completely? Eh... not quite. I recall Mystique having a definite maternal quality in the cartoons, which may very well develop with more films, but she doesn't quite have that as of yet. From her portrayal here, though, I could easily make the mental connection through time. Last I'm gonna touch on is Nicholas Hoult as Beast. Not the greatest, really. Not terrible, but not all that good. Acting: 8/10Writing: Why is Professor X in this movie? I know, I already mentioned that, but Singer made it a point to legitimize TLS as canon. Plot holes be damned, let's move on. As the name suggests, this is a time travel film. As with any time-based film, the science of how time travel works is a bit fuzzy, but it manages to make enough sense in the context of the film. I mean, if Catwoman can control the weather, I think we can accept the transferring of consciousness through time as a thing. The plot of the film is competent and doesn't linger too much, but I would've liked a couple sequences to go on a little longer. An example would be the subplot with Xavier's mutant power suppressant. We have two scenes on it, but that's pretty much it. It's somewhat referenced in a later scene involving Cerebro, but it's still fairly inconsequential. Most of the dialog was solid, so I have no real complaints there. The plot itself, as I said, is competent and easy to understand. It's a well-written story that I feel serves the purpose of being accessible to Marvel fans that want to see X-Men characters do X-Men character things and casual moviegoers that may just want to be entertained. The story doesn't take too many twists and turns, but I really liked it for what it was. Writing: 7.5/10Aesthetics: The effects in this film were pretty much what you'd expect from a big budget film brought to you by 20th Century Fox. They were good, but that's par for the course. If they were bad, it would be criminal. Something I feel I should give a nod to is the music, though. Days Of Future Past is solid in the sound department and features the score from the previous X-Men films. It's nostalgic and adds more to the aesthetic of the film. Short and sweet, it's nice to look at and the quality visuals are enhanced by proficient sound design. Aesthetics: 7/10Action: The action in Days Of Future Past isn't what I'd call remarkable, but it's definitely enhanced by the film's pacing. It's no rare occurrence for there to be ten to fifteen minutes without a noteworthy battle, but those that happen just serve to have more of an impact. I'd call this more of a skirmish film. While there may be several "action" scenes interspersed throughout, they're relatively low-key and based more on tension than outright frantic testosterone. A decent amount of focus is given to stealth, so the bigger events are that much more satisfying. One that comes to mind is the occasional cut to the future where the last of the X-Men try desperately to defend their fortification from Sentinels. We are treated to some awesome fights there. Magneto shows us why he's the coolest comic book villain Marvel has to offer, Bishop blasts away everything in his path and Colossus does battle like a boss. All that's cool, but I was most impressed by the girl with the gateway powers. She was hardcore and made many of the action scenes as special as they were. When she did her thing, I was like "yeah! You go, Portal chick!" I think her name's Blink, but I'm not sure. Action: 8Appeal To Marvel Fans: Pretty much the most important part for any film is its appeal to its target demographic. As I've said, we have a decent amount of X-Men characters on display. Some better than others, but we are given at least a glimpse at most of our favorites. My only real complaint is that there was no Gambit. That's a downer, as he's my favorite. The presentation and tone of the film looks and feels like an X-Men movie, which is a definite plus. I feel this will please most X-Men fans, so I'd call it a successful film to say the least. It's nice to see Bryan Singer back at the helm of the franchise, as he's done wonders so far. Appeal: 8.5

X-men: Days of Future Past is a movie depicting rivalry of humans and mutants. In this movie, X-men fights a war for the survival of mutants in two generations: future and past. In the future, Sentinels(robots) built by humans with supernatural powers pose a threat to survival of mutants. Professor X, Magneto, along with the mutant community try to save the lives of mutants from this threat. They send back Logan(Wolverine) into the past with help of Kitty Padre, a mutant having the ability to send a person's consciousness into the person's past, to change something that made the humans to develop Sentinels. After a series of action in the past and the future, movie comes to a conclusion. The storyline of the movie is too good. I really liked the action scene when Quicksilver, a mutant who can move at supersonic speeds, saving everyone.The 3D effects lets you dive deep into the movie. The movie lets you wonder if at some point of time humans evolves into two races, will they fight with each other for dominance and existence.

If your Xmen fans, all puzzles seen in this movie is a slave of this film. Movie Xmen state all the miss points on the comics. Beautifully made and finish was a Great surprise, Marvel gave a wonderful job on this film.for my review no spoiler. crafted perfection of plot, rearrange with unknown scenario. The movie was filled with action that mind set was getting great and advance comic design. but never the list this movie solve the missing piece of the Xmen comic. Recommend this movie watch. if you watch the old cartoon version or comic reader you will solve the hidden puzzle that you have been not seen on this move.great good DC movies!

This is an incredible movie directed perfectly with an astounding cast, not a single cast member lets this movie down. Hugh Jackman reprises his role as wolverine and nails it showing the audience what he is really capable of, I can't say anything bad anything bad about the acting in this movie it's superb.The plot is amazing and there are easter eggs for fans of the series/comics, there are points that are extremely intense as well as emotional such as the ending where we can see what happens in the future while Wolverine's subconscious in the past. I can't really say anything bad except for that I feel the ending was a little rushed with how Magneto got taken down. This movie is the perfect X-movie so far with intense and powerful scenes, great acting, a great plot and amazing little easter eggs for fans such as myself to find.

Speaking as someone whose life began in 1973; I found this movie particularly worth seeing.The dysopian future's visual effects were very good. Some action sequences were disappointing - particularly Bishop's. If all he does is shoot a gun once every scene when someone gives him energy he can't be expected to be very effective. The storyline was OK; but some of the hallmark flashbacks of previous X-MEN films were a little unnecessary. Each film from the 2000 film to now must stand on their own two feet. But since this is a time-travel movie; I would guess that it makes some kind of sense. I half-expected the scene where Logan almost loses the connection he has with the past - to accidentally learn his entire past and recover his full memory through Xavier's mental link between his two younger and older selves.Hopefully the next film X-MEN Apocalypse deals with my favorite X-MEN Storyline Arc: Beyond Good And Evil. Where the X-MEN fight Apocalypse's attempt to destroy all time and space in an alternative zone called "The Axis Of Time".

I want to add a goof i've noticed.. magneto used a single bullet to pull raven towards himself. Mass of the bullet should be so small comparing to raven s body so it would go out instead of pulling the whole body together.

I usually do not write reviews. The feeling that urged me to write is not the one of admiring the movie above all and let the world know about it. It was not a dislike neither, because I enjoy X-men movies since the possibilities with characters are just immense. No, what pushed me to write is that sense of enjoying a film but seeing that its being highly overrated.Yes, it's a summer blockbuster so no need to be too harsh on that as long as it entertains and doesn't make you check your watch. And yes, this was probably one of the best among all X-men movies for all the reasons everybody says but somehow fails to specify.Overall, the movie had some serious plot wholes and left some extraordinary characters untapped. It was an injustice to the work that had been done in the First Class on introducing the depth of Erik and Xavier's characters. It also had some very flat quotes, especially Xavier's lines were quite poor, and not even mentioning the JFK related ones... The movie should have been 30 minutes longer to better set the tone and give it the drama and epicness it deserved because, hey, does one have to remind how Dramatic and Epic changing history and saving the entire world is?At the end, it was merely an entertaining action movie with a lot of very cool characters (who could possibly not love that Quicksilver character?!) but no depth, unless you already know the whole story and try to imagine that part yourself.Being the best X-men movie ever done does not make it a great movie, considering the low it came from - not doing it better than the X3 would have been a disaster. I give it 7 points because it was very entertaining but could have been done much better.

reviews.review_title: the best in the series so far..
reviews.content: what a movie it is. I never expected this kind of a x men movie. If you had liked x men:first class,then it would be a double treat to you. One of the best movie of the year so far..... The first was something awesome. I never had seen this kind of plot line in super-hero movies. Performance of Mystique,young Erik & Charles were superb. There were no enough twists in the film,but also it keeps interesting & thrilling up to end. Photography & music were amazing. And a piece of good visual effects. Bryan Singer's direction is the best part of it. Hope it will cross $1 billion milestone. I am waiting for the sequence which would be directed by Him.Whats bad:The 3D effects can felt only in the climax.MUST WATCH IT

I went to cinema on 24 May and i just loved it. It was even better than "X-Men: First Class". I have no words how amazing is this film. I loved this movie. I recommend to X-Men fans and non-fans. This was really amazing. So beautiful, really great film. I loved everything about this movie. The cast, the plot and everything about this movie was really awesome & interesting. I really recommend to watch this movie. Really worth your time & money. Highly entertaining & interesting movie. Awesome movie. Just awesome. Everyone should see it now. This movie even better than "The Wolverine". See it now. Enjoy it now. This movie is really deserves your time. Great movie. I especially liked Quicksilver in this amazing movie. Magneto just stole my heart.

See I loved the movie and is best X men movie till date, if you are going to try and find explanation for so called holes you won't find any.
I had two virtues to look at this1. The events of 1973 of mystique killing stark leads to this movie. Now you should think that X -men , X- men united and X- men last stand never happened and that is why Xavier and others are shown alive. So if stark was killed this is the next movie after X-men first class and forget all parts ever happened. This way you will love the movie.2. That makes sense in making all the X men movies and in X- men last stand whatever happened is the true happennings, Xavier is no more , Jean and all othersSo This movie is just about ifs and buts, had this happened that would have happened and had this thing changed this way those( first 3 parts happened)Wat I gain from this movie is that stark was never killed by mystique and the events of past in this movie led to first 3 X men movies and that is to be believed. The future events shown never happened because the purpose was served.
I will say watch this movie without thinking much and just believe the future events shown in this movie never happened cause sentinel program never happened.So a thumbs up to the first 3 parts .An altogether perspective is that after first class it was X men and then united and then last stand. So DofP never happened not in past not in future.Greatest movie

Well , all I can say , is that this movie is PERFECT . It is in the same level as TDK . It is astonishing . If you didn't see it , get the F**k up of your chair and go see it. This movie has power , has a lot of power .I never felt so excited about a superhero movie IN 6 YEARS . It is absolutely BRILLIANT. And I am not even a X-Men fan . The way it's made , the story .. is it original ? Absolutely not . But who said it needs to be , to be perfect as this masterpiece of superhero movies ?Seriously , I want to watch this another 3 times like I did with the 2008 TDK . Why i Am Saying This Bcoz i Love Speed i Love Power i Love Time Travel i Love Mutant As i Am One of there Kind . The X-men days of future past will give you all the experiences that a x-men movies franchise Fan want or Moreover a wolverine fan. The older Charles and magneto comes together to stop the extinction of mutants as well as humans and send wolverine to 50 year back at 1973 to do cover the mistakes done by the young Raven who kills the Dr. Bolivar Trask ,Dr. Bolivar Trask making weapon called sentinels against mutants . In actual Past Raven kills Dr. Bolivar Trask and get captured which using his DNA all anti mutants weapons made who adapts to any mutants power and killed all mutant in 50 years. Our hero Logan send to past to change this back and save Mutanity. Check Out the action In Between Past & future.

By far the best X-Men movie to date.... While it diverges from the official comic book story line, the plot is still the same. Robots have decimated the human and mutant population and taken over the world! While that comes as no surprise to die hard fans of the franchise, this movie is finally the one we have been waiting for since the franchise started. It's almost a do-over in a way because it corrects many many many of the mistakes of the first two films. For instance Storm no longer spouts cheesy lines before activating her powers; Magneto is the powerhouse he always should have been; and Hugh Jackman finally shows us a decent portrayal of Wolverine on screen. F-I-N-A-L-L-YThis movie has breathed new life into a franchise I thought would never be done right on screen; and in doing so, it has set the stage for the coming of the Age of Apocalypse by making the mutant presence known to the entire world. Thank you Marvel & Bryan Singer for proving me wrong!

When I first heard about this film project, I thought it was great that someone was going to attempt one of the truly groundbreaking story lines of Marvel comics. I also thought that the filmmakers would find some way to mess it up. After all, though I loved X-Men: First Class, I wasn't sure that the magic would continue with this film. Rather I was dreading something closer to X-Men 3. Though there are some points that are not made clear (how is it that Wolverine can be sent to the past in the way he is? It is different from the way a Kitty Pryde is sent back in the comics, which did make some sense). If you are willing to let that point go (and you have to, or the film will be no fun), I think this does a great job with the idea of time travel and how some errors can be corrected before they are set in stone. And we also see a rather nice story of redemption.

reviews.review_title: The best x-men yet. Definitely worth watching
reviews.content: There was lots of hype for this film and I was hoping that it would keep up to this hype, and it truly did. From the start of the film to the end, every bit kept me interested. Not once was I waiting for a "good part". I thought that the movie would just be based on wolverine, but I was glad to see all the characters, both the first class and original cast, to all get a good amount of time. Also, I was glad to see wolverine was not the only important character of this story. I thought that wolverine would be the main centre of the film, but other characters were just as important as him.Now quicksilver, he was absolutely amazing and hilarious. His scene was definitely one of my favourite. The special effects, the humour and the importance of his scene is why his scene was one of my favourite.The sentinels..... they are now one of my favourite enemies in marvel films. During the film the story went from 1973 to 2023 every now and then, and the pure strength and power of the sentinels shows why the population on earth is nearly extinct. The sentinels are formidable opponents, not once did I ever think "how are mutant population at risk?" Also, there is a simple good explanation on how the sentinels are really hard to defeat.The time travel concept was way better than I thought. I, myself like movies with time travel, but I had a feeling that it was going to do a complicated time travel concept.But it was very simple (a mild spoiler now). Kitty prides phasing ability evolved so she can send people's consciousness back in time. So she sends wolverine back in time to alter history. But wolverine's consciousness can only stay in his past self if kitty pride is alive. So wolverine has to alter history before the sentinels finds the 2023 xmen. This is about how complicated it can get.The specials effects/CGI, whatever you want to call it, was really good. Seeing magneto lift up the stadium or the 2023 xmen fighting the sentinels, not once did I ever think the effects bad. Not once did it remind me of the xmen origins wolverine special effects.Bolivar Trask however, was not as intimidating and scary as expected. Although he was the creator of the sentinels, he was overshadowed by a different enemy. Peter dinklage still done a good performance as trask, showing his motivation of the sentinel program.Apart from that which this minor fault did not have a great impact, xmen days of future past is one of the greatest films yet and you should definitely watch this film.

reviews.review_title: The best X men movie yet, by far
reviews.content: The best X-men movie yet, by farIt's been a long time since I left a movie theatre simply too stunned for words, I think it was "Inception", 2010. The writers have pulled out all the stops here and meshed together THE best comic storyline adaptation I've seen bar none. Growing up in the nineties, waking up on a Saturday morning, the one and only cartoon to look out for was X-men, so I think I can say I'm biased toward the franchise, but with good reason; the storywriters have produced something with so much depth and complexity that makes other comic film adaptations look, basically, for kids. OK, I enjoyed "The Avengers" as well, don't get me wrong.5 movies, 1 original comic story, weaved together by perhaps the strongest cast available. Perhaps it just me, but ever since "The Matrix", action movies have basically been "same same, but different". What people crave is stories, and what a story this is. How can I describe it? The fact that after what I consider was the worst Wolverine movie (Yes, "The Wolverine" was horribly disappointing), Hugh Jackman has finally got Wolverine (aka Logan) down. Perhaps his own experience playing him, along with the requirements of the movie for a more mature Wolverine, really come together here. A lead supporting actor. Is it even possible? Yes, somehow Hugh Jackman has pulled it off. Like the other veterans in the movie (Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellan) he's brought something tangible, credible and humble to the ensemble.Jennifer Lawrence, James McAvoy, Michael Fassbender, Peter Dinklage, Halle Berry, Bingbing Fan... you know what, I could go on praising this cast for another 1000 words, however I'm going to stop now.OK, let me rewind a little, 5 movies, one comic arc.Five movies? X-men, X-men 2, X-men – Last stand, X- men origins – Wolverine and X-men – First class. 1 comic arc? #141 – 142 Chris Claremont, John Byrneand Terry Austin. 1981. OK, so the comic speaks for itself. But how about the movies? Well, firstly the actors, for the most part, there are the same actors from all five of those movies featured in "X-men – Days of Future Past". This is a fantastic bit of casting. It gives so much more credibility to different actors playing the same characters across time. Next; flashback sequences. Third; inferences from the characters themselves. This mash up, so seamlessly knitted with both subtle and overt political references, personal tragedy, friendship, betrayal, unrequited love and, of course, the Michael Bay style action sequences we've come to love and expect from our favourite X-men movies.OK a quick word on powers. Some superhero movies (especially in my opinion "Superman" movies) play down the powers of their heroes. Not in an X-men movie. Not in THE X-men movie. We all know Magneto is awesome. We all know The Professor is awesome. And we all enjoy seeing Wolverine rip someone a new one. Here in "X-men Days of Future Past" we get to see their awesomeness, but flawed. Flawed in their physical weaknesses, flawed in their selfish desires, flawed in their humanity. This does wonders for the movie. It creates a dynamic which accentuates the lighter parts and allows for the action sequences to have greater impact. What Bryan Singer has managed to do is create a symphony; complete with prelude, development, low dark tones interspersed with lighter ones, building up into a colossal cacophony, rising into a crescendo and concluding with style. Needless to say, I've got to see the next one.

This film was by far my favourite out of all the Xmen films. It has all the same special Sci fi effects as the previous films do, and a similar compelling storyline that is so intense it has its viewers on the edge of their seats. The thing that I found so awesome about this particular film, is the essential step back through time, the only chance the mutants have to save their kind and defeat the sentinels from wiping them out completely. We see some of the mutants when they are younger. They are stubborn and reckless, and ever so beautiful, like helllloooooo Magneto! Who would've though old Gandalf (Yes, I also see him as Gandalf in Xmen) was such a stud in his younger years! Even Professor X, was quite the handsome fellow. We see how their personalities have changed over time and we feel the struggles they went through in their younger years in contrast to where they are in the future. Everything gets pieced together for us. The ending is a bit of a tear jerker - that is if you've seen and loved all the films, although slightly sad because we don't get the perfect happy ending for wolverine that we're all hoping for. Overall, absolutely awesome film, I'll be watching it again very soon!

reviews.review_title: Don't know what the hypes about
reviews.content: This is one of a number of recent marvel superhero movies receiving undeserved gratuitous praise. I'm afraid for all the above eight user reviews, this action flick amounts to a disappointingly average movie. It really feels like the crew blew all their creative talent on one, admittedly fantastic, action set piece. Said set piece is certainly deserving of praise and if the rest of the film had delivered to the same degree i too would be foaming at the mouth. Unfortunately as soon as the scene is over, it's star is relieved of duty and left to watch the finale of the film unfold from his living room on the TV. I only bothered to sit through the entire finale because i had paid £7 for the ticket, so i really cant say for the life of me why he did.

reviews.review_title: Great movie. Logan's past now confusing
reviews.content: I really enjoyed this movie! Magneto is freaking nuts man. Everything about it I thought was done great, except one but left me really confused?!! How could Logan just "Wake up" back in the new time line, but have also been active in it? He's clearly got a past with all of them, but is now some how completely unaware of it?? Did everyone have to reintroduce themselves to him or do his memory's come back??

reviews.review_title: Amazing, so much more than a simple superhero/action film
reviews.content: I was looking forward to seeing this film for such a long time and I made a point of ignoring as many trailers as possible so that I could experience everything the film had to offer for the first time in the cinema, and I'm so glad that I did. I can honestly say this is one of the best films I have EVER seen. Everything has been done fantastically, the acting is brilliant, the action sequences are awesome, most importantly the film has such a good story that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Seeing the comparison between the characters from the past and future is very interesting as well as very believable, the acting is spot on and you can really see the characters come to life. Without any spoilers the scene after the credits is definitely worth waiting for, that'll hype you up even more when the film has come to an end. I definitely recommend this film to anyone out there and easily rate it a 10/10.

reviews.review_title: The best X-men ever. DO NOT miss it
reviews.content: I went for the 3D version (would you rather watch b&w TV?) for obvious reasons, and it was insane. This is the first X-men that really really intrigued and immersed me into the action and found the story complex, yet easy to understand. It's not trying to be over complex and confuse the audience so that they are in awe of the movie, but end up not figuring out anything. The only part just before the end got a little monotonous and some parts needed further explanation. I think Peter Dinklage is an unbelievable actor, and love his roles. The producers/directors could have used his talents a little more by making his role more witty and intelligent (not denying that it wasn't already).I can compare this to Iron Man, and that's saying a lot.

reviews.review_title: More than just a blockbuster or reboot
reviews.content: DoFP is a perfect course correction for the X-men franchise, and Bryan Singer pulls it off perfectly. The story is well developed and never slow. The action sequences are amazing in 3-D and don't feel forced or overwhelming. The thing that really struck me was the opening for FOX to continue with either cast. After Last Stand it looked like the studio had painted itself into a corner and was forced into earlier timelines unwillingly. But looking back, it's almost as if the earlier timelines were just an aside, so that the characters are better developed when it came around to this movie. I keep reading about this being a summer blockbuster...and it is. But the story has depth and heart, which keeps it true to the comics. Walking out of the theater I was ready to buy a ticket to the next X-men film. This is not one you want to pass up.
After many disappointments, this has to be the best one since X2. Hopefully, as I continue my first time watch through, the films can keep up this momentum.

A flurry of emotions was this spectacle of cinema. The character arcs compel the viewers interest and empathy alike as the circumstances surrounding the X-men is unfolded. Jam packed action scenes are plentiful as the mutants push their limits against the sentinel robots. But most of all, and which comprises the majority of the film, Magneto, Professor X, Wolverine and Mystique are the focal plot drivers of the narrative and as such we begin to delve deeper into their struggles and their journeys as mutant leaders of Earth.If you enjoy epic science fiction films then this movie will be for you. The cinematography is clean and the acting is second to none.

X men first class was a great way to restart the franchise. . My hopes drop down a little bit when i heard Matthews Vaughan left the movie. So I went to watch it with low expectation. Well you all know the story so no point talking about it. To just brief you a little bit about the story. The future is being rule by sentinel, who both have a control of mutant and human. Mutants face an extinction, so the x-men team in the future sends Wolverine back to change the past by stopping a certain assassination from happening. The movie handles the time travelling part well, time travels can be a complex thing to explain to the viewers. But here you can understand it but yet you'll still have a lot of questions in the end because when they change the past then the future in x men 1 2 & 3 changes. There are a bit of unanswered questions in this film which is frustrating and I don't know why filmmakers always choose to ignore them, a five minutes explanation would be better than a scene which include some lame jokes. But apart from a slightly questionable story, the movie was enjoyable. Once again the highlight of the movie is the interaction between the young Erik and Charles. Fassbender and McAviy, both seem so smoothly into their character. Michael Fassbender is fantastic in magneto. His sole purpose of keeping mutants alive and protecting them from the society through extreme measure is so understandable that you have every reason to support him. While James McAvoy as Charles other hand is a revolution. It amazing how much of wisdom along with emotions he manages to show on screen and those moments give you a good idea what the future Xavier is. This movie and the previous one contain all the landmark and understanding of what both Magneto and Xavier grow up to be. You cant hate either of them,because you'll just end up loving both of them. It hard to choose between them. And there interaction between them is fantastic. You can feel the sadness, love, hate and respect they have for each other. And the way these two actor express their emotion together is nothing short but spectacular. But again while this is the best part of the movie, it sadly the bad thing about cause those scene between Erik and Charles are just too short. In First class, they both were together from the start to the end. And had loads of moment where the difference can be seen. Here it's just short. That's why i feel they were wrong to bring up a story like this which involves the previous class. They could have just pick off when first class left. And show how Erik continues his journey to become and Magneto and Charles to Xavier. The interaction between the old Xavier and Magneto and Old Xavier with Charles is another touching moment of superb directing, acting and writing. Mystic sadly is not effective as she was in first class. I loved her in first class especially her relationship with beast, Charles and Erik. But here she seems lost. I blame the writers for her character. They make her on her own. Apart from the story, their are plenty of action scenes, they are good at times and okay at times,nothing ground breaking. The camera work is nicely done here. Music is good and bad at times. I miss the first class music to be honest. Especially the magneto theme they had. All in all it was an enjoyable movie, a bit too strong for children. They might have trouble understanding it.

I found the movie to be a wonderful spin on a classic story. It was a pleasure to see such a blockbuster cast set aside their ego for a well built story and not demand more screen time. There will always be complaints about why one member was or wasn't in the story but the team they assembled worked will together. I also enjoy how the franchise tries to create a historical reference by tying the stories to real events such as the Cuban Missile Crisis in the First Class movie. As a whole the story nicely tied the franchise together and presented some intriguing team possibilities for the next installment in the franchise. I can only hope that "Age of Apocalypse" is as good with Singer at the Helm. Can't wait to take the family to go see it when I go again :)

reviews.review_title: ...without spoiling anything, I will say this...
reviews.content: I came into this movie with the highest of expectations, and it did not disappoint. "Days" ranks as one of the best Marvel movies to date, but is it the best one?Marvel just gets better and better with their movie adaptations, and the way the time travel was handled and explained, it actually worked.The acting was superb, but then again, what do you expect from this all star-studded cast? McAvoy, Fassbender, Stewart, McKellen, and Jackman are amazing established actors, but this stage belonged to Jennifer Lawrence as Mystique, and to Evan Peters, who looked like he was having the time of his life in the role of Quicksilver.There are going to be the detractors who are going to say the film had way too many characters and there was no character development. If anything, each character had decent time to showcase their powers, and in a film like this, that's about as much character development the audience needed (for those who do not follow the comic books).So, in response to my earlier questionAs much as I would love to give this movie a resounding "Yes" as the best Marvel film to datethat distinction still goes to "Captain America: The Winter Soldier."And this is coming from an X-Men fan since '85.But, damn, "Days" is an extremely close second
The rogue cut is 10 because it is perfect , the theatrical version is 9 🙂👍
Don't waste your time on this. Watch the original X-Men trilogy instead. Or any of those three films. I don't have anything else to say, but it says my review is too short.

This is a good action movie with pretty good special effects.A very good job done by the "Returned to the Franchise" director Bryan Singer. Since the movie has a large cast,the movie unqualified the viewers to know some characters and their origins, which could be done in the up-coming movies.Coming to the movie, at first story was ordinarily understandable, then in the middle, because of the fast running of the plot left the viewers a bit confusing, but this cloud fades away in the end. The end also left some untied spaces, which is good for the franchise to leave some suspense to the fans. Trailer gave-up most of the plot, which makes fans miss the old ambiance in the movie theaters. Finally, to the makers, a little suspense and twists could be good in the movie, without giving away the major plot in the trailers.

For someone who has never read the comics and is relatively new to the X-Men franchise, I thoroughly enjoyed the film from start to finish. When I saw X-men 1st Class, as it was a prequel, it was fairly easy for me to follow and thought it had a fairly good story, good acting and strong cast. However my biggest let down was the poor CGI effects at some points in the film. It's a small matter but little things like that can weaken a film for me. Therefore, I was glad to see that the previous's films short coming had been amended. X-men: Days of future past impressed me with a well driven story line switching from future to past which really worked well as the transitions were smooth and effective. The cast is also arguably the strongest line up in any X-men film with superb acting by the likes of Hugh Jackman, Michael Fassbender and Peter Dinklage playing this installments bad guy (to an extent). Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellen also return for their old roles as Professor X and Magneto which is nice but they have considerably less screen time than their younger counterparts which is fine as the story primarily takes place when Professor X and Magneto were younger. All in all, X-men: Days of future past is a well rounded movie which makes effective use of linking the past and the future well (even if it is a series reboot like Star Trek) and with good acting, light humor, comic book references and a good story, I would definitely recommend you watch this film even if you're not an X-Men fan. I would recommend you watch 1st Class beforehand to fill you in on some details though (or at least read up on it). Don't forget the clip at the very end of the credits too.

reviews.review_title: The reborn of X Men in the Big Screen
reviews.content:
X-Men Days of Future Past is a fast moving movie, its story jumps from past to present. It doesn't matter if you don't know about Comics, because is a well written plot for all the audience, maybe you have to see its prequel for understand some scenes, but you can understand it without it, it's an entertaining movie for all people, with a lot of good characteres, good performances of very famous actors, some entertaining action scenes and an ending that make you feel satisfied with the movie. The message of the movie is that the mankind is one and that wars mustn't exist, we all can live in a Pacific world without racism and fear of the unknown. 
This movie corrects the mistakes of X Men: The last stand and open a new vision of mutants in the 20th Century.

With an ensemble cast and such a brobdingnagian doze of X-men, Days of Future Past works wonders with the screenplay and the screen time that all x-men share. The X-men, ushering in their mutant traits to complement the visual effects, go berserk fighting their invincible nemesis The Sentinels. The action, neither too boisterous nor mundane is a tempting and titillating. Hugh Jackman and Jennifer Lawrence anchor the plot cogently. Its a Mystique/Raven cum Wolverine show that centrifuges an entertaining solution of thrill as events in the past are mutilated to save the future and render it secure. The constant fear of the future being delved into darkness keeps up the interest. Magneto's mettle outshines. All in all the ride back to future is a compelling one, joyous and enjoyable !

reviews.review_title: Great movie !! But doesn't justify previous movies!!
reviews.content: Everything about this movie is great !! The cast, the acting, the details and graphics !! All in all a fantastic movie but personally for me it didn't justify the previous movies !! Like why the hell even make X-men origins if they were not gonna use it for future movies !! And also they didn't explain how did the sentinels got activated so many years after the Trask is dead and destroyed what look liked the whole planet when their purpose was to just eliminate the mutants for mankind to survive !!As not being a comic book reader but a movie fan I kinda felt missed out on some of the details !! But even though being missed out on some details The director Bryan Singer did a great job to keep the movie balanced and humorous and I was not bored for even a second of the movie even though a little unsatisfied !!

reviews.review_title: Some parts good, some parts bad.
reviews.content: Everybody dies in a future that never happens. Some scenes don't make any sense.However, some parts were brilliant such as when Raven is in the middle of the front garden of the white house and shoots Magneto. I also liked the character who was so fast he could appear to stop time. It is worth watching the movie just for that one scene.The film involves time travel and is well written but near to the end most of the characters die in the future only for the past to change meaning they don't die after all. That part I found terrible. Don't let this review stop you watching the film though.

Brilliant film, the only one of the X-Men franchise to so far give me goose bumps throughout. Everything is just so satisfying, so cohesive and gosh Magneto is as badass as he has ever been. Despite there being a few innocuous concerns I have with some aspects of the script, it would be nitty picking to the extreme to point them out. The stakes feel as grand as ever yet it comes off as a very rounded film. Highly recommended!
greatly paced, a great story, and great performances, though the story is very similar to the last installment it's still fun to revisit.
I love this movie so much, like it's prior installment, it works well, a lot less emotion but it makes sense as a sequel and is very good.
Even on rewatch the effects are stellar. All of the leading class surpass what is expected of a superhero movie. I am so glad this movie exists.

Wow what a watch the whole time travel through the mind is brilliant Charles and magneto shine they are both amazing wolverine is amazing the whole film is breathtaking with amazing depth and story telling. The time travel is amazing also shows how good young magneto and Charles are
Best Marvel movie to hit the big screen
The movie had the brilliant idea of setting up a post apocalyptic world in which not even the great powers of any mutants could ensure their survival. It had great action along with a chilling tone.
Best X-Men related project ever behind Logan. (As of 2022)

By far the best X-men/mutant/marvel movie Fox did. Nothing else in the franchise comes close. Logan was great, Deadpool was a good movie but far different. The rouge cut wasn't that different but worth watching. Can't wait for the MCU X-men but it already sounds like they are going to change Magneto and professor x. Also rumors of Hugh jackman returning as Wolverine for Deadpool 3 and I think it's a great idea to give him a proper send off in the MCU
This is the darkest superhero movie and one of the best. It deals with humanity at a very high level and presents it at its most bleak.
What can I say? It's an amazing film.
They really stepped it up with the cast and story. Acting is great. Story is great
One of the best  movies
Best xmen movie ever made, sentinels sucked though
The best next to the first and X2.
Best move of the trilogy!
Being memorable and appealing, Days of Future Past puts the best elements from different timelines in one epic mashup with gut-wrenching moments and spectacular action.
Best of Movies/TV Series Collection

Evan Peters as Quicksilver was great. Especially the Time in a bottle scene. 
Not the worst Xmen film.

I had an idea that this movie was a bad-explained mess, an empty plot with bad script. However, I rewatched it and my perception changed completely!
It is actually one of the best movies in the franchise so far. They explain the time-traveling thing with simple but effective concepts. The plot is crazy! Every single decision affects what these mutant's want to achieve.
It is organized, structures, and feels very fresh and new.
Another awesome part for me was watching both generations of actors interacting with each other.

Taking each important element from each film and bringing it into one. X-Men Days of Future Past is a perfectly balanced film that bring together both the old and new cast members and make it one of the best X-Men installments.

Imagine everything First Class did right (Which was everything) and just made each even more refined. More complex character interactions, more complex plot and more ambitious action sequences. The Acting is easily as strong as the first as well. This is arguably even better than its predecessor but is no question a All Time Classic Action Movie and All Time Classic in General.
Spechless, one of the best movies of all time

X Men Days of Future Past is my favorite movie in the franchise if not the best of the saga. The premise is not original but the way it is staged is spectacular when dramatic. The film begins with the immediate death of very powerful mutants and then continues with the real beginning of the plot or return (not physically) to the past to prevent the creation of the Sentinel Project. The atmosphere is centered and the photography adapts well to sunny tones in the past and dark tones in the future. As usual the soundtrack takes your breath away and adjusts properly to the tone of the film. The narration and the editing are well structured and realized, with a clear and flowing alternation between the sequences of the past and those of the future. The characters have an incredible characterization: the young Xavier who a man totally different from what we knew because he walks, is no longer hopeful and isolated but thanks to Logan he becomes Professor X again. The young Magneto has the same characterization he had in X Men First Class but more expanded and ultimately makes a spectacular speech. Raven, who is the centerpiece of the story, has an extraordinary evolution. The character of Bolivar Trask is very well written, he is man who, despite having done cruel and brutal actions, just wanted to make the world a better place without knowing that he would have created the villains of the film that is the Sentinells. They are perfect machines that adapt to every mutant they encounter and, having no conscience, they kill their targets without mercy. In fact, there are various tear-jerking scenes where these robots kill many mutants including the ones we love. The ending is something amazing and exciting without adding anything else. So X Men Days of Future Past is a profound, complete film that can also be watched as a film in itself for those who have not followed the saga since in the film they make a good summary of everything.

While it does suffer from many of the issues other superhero movies suffer from, "X-Men: Days of Future Past" is one of the most important of the X-Men films and is an extremely welcome addition to the franchise. The story and plot feel unique, the villain(s) are all done very well, and the action sequences are terrific to watch. A hopeful and resonant finale to the X-Men story.

Director Bryan Singer's superhero sci-fi adventure X-Men: Days of Future Past (2014) brings Chris Claremont's time travel comic book to life with a resplendent optimism for our future with a moving finale that effectively and emotionally concludes Singer's version of The X-Men on the silver screen. I appreciate the theme of people being able to change and that we choose our own path to walk down in life as nothing is set in stone. Singer completely understands these mutant characters to their heart.

It's really poignant seeing all these beloved comic book characters fighting for their mutant lives as Days of Future Past speaks for human equality, peace, diplomacy, kindness, patience, progress, tolerance, and acceptance. Writers Simon Kinberg, Matthew Vaughn, and Jane Goldman really write character arcs we can get invested in and think of satisfying conclusions for everyone. We all change and grow in our brief, yet unique lives. I hated Days of Future Past when I first saw it after loving First Class. However, now Days of Future Past finally touched me and was thoroughly enjoyable and thoughtful after revisiting it. Who knows what the future will bring for humanity as all we can do is live our lives appreciating the ones we love around us, choosing to be nicer everyday.

Hugh Jackman finds inner peace as Logan once more with several emotionally compelling conversations with Charles Xavier, including Days of Future Past's remarkable final scene. Jackman gives some of his most thoughtful acting here as the ferocious Wolverine and reflective Logan. Hugh Jackman has carried The X-Men franchise into something worth watching and he gives them a purpose and course correction with Days of Future Past's retcons and revisionist history. Patrick Stewart keeps the heart of Charles Xavier pure and driven towards his mission of uniting all mutants through understanding, hope, and patience. I love his tender and kind Professor X. Ian McKellen is again magnificent as Magneto as he conjures up his superpowers to wield metal like bullets and crash ships together. His very presence has real gravitas as the sinister and complex Magneto.

James McAvoy is gripping as the devastated and deterred Charles Xavier at his low point. It's wonderful seeing Hugh Jackman's Logan encourage and reassure McAvoy's moving Professor X to find and house mutants and form The X-Men as his life is worthwhile. McAvoy is incredibly vulnerable and sensitive here to every little nuance of Xavier's insecurities, failings, and hopes for a safe future for all of humanity and mutants alike. Michael Fassbender is fearsome as Magneto with that uniquely commanding edge and steadfast ideal that he is doing what is best for mutants.

Jennifer Lawrence makes you believe in Mystique shapeshifting abilities and her hurt feelings that she is doing what is right in her own way. Lawrence gives a fantastic dramatic performance full of conviction. Nicholas Hoult is cool as Beast, but best as Hank McCoy supporting Charles' endeavors. Halle Berry's storm gets some serious action sequences alongside Magneto of all people. I love Ellen Page's performance as the hurting and focused Kitty Pryde as we get to see her vanish through walls and travel through time. Page should have been given an entire movie about Kitty Pryde. I hope Elliot Page continues to get roles now that he's out and proud. Anna Paquin gets a cute cameo as Rogue that really got me emotional. She was the heart and soul of the first X-Men movie.

Peter Dinklage is fabulous as the crazed and hateful scientist Trask, who wants Mystique's DNA to create mutant killing robots. He's very interesting in each of his scenes. Evan Peters steals his scenes as the hilarious and hyper speed sprinting mutant Quicksilver. Josh Helman is pretty intimidating as William Styker. He lets you see how warped Trask's speeches and ideology made Stryker. Shawn Ashmore is as cool and nice a hero as ever as Bobby Drake or Iceman. Omar Sy is neat as Bishop and Daniel Cudmore is killer as the mighty Colossus. I really loved Fan Bingbing as Blink with her dimension opening mutant superpowers and expressive face.

Famke Janssen, James Marsden, Kelsey Grammer, and Lucas Till's cameos are appreciated as they're really affecting in their brief appearances. Michael Lerner, Chris Claremont, and Len Wein are fun cameos as the skeptical senators Dinklage must present his robot idea to before Congress.

Editor John Ottman gets you engaged with his sharp and fast cuts for a breezy 132 minutes. Cinematographer Newton Thomas Sigel continues his amazing and touching close-up shots with ambitious wide shots for all the displays of awesome mutant powers. John Myhre's production design is cool for the 1970's Charles Xavier School for Gifted Youngsters and recreates The White House. 

The visual effects artists' CGI for Xavier's mind powers, Magneto's creative lethal uses of metal, Blink's portals, and Kitty Pryde's time travel and wall phasing are excellent. Composer John Ottman's score is melancholic and rousing with splendid melodies again for Days of Future Past. Loved the flamboyant costume changes and believable make-up work.

In all, Days of Future Past holds up to the passage of time with an emotionally gripping narrative.

When I first saw this movie, I adored it.  I loved everything it did for the franchise, action films, and the superhero genre as a whole.  Now, years later and many superhero films onward, it still holds up as a great film, but maybe not the landmark piece I held it up as.  For one, it's still got that uncomfortable Bryan Singer length.  By the 1 ½ mark, I was about ready to check out.  For an over 2 hour movie, that's a problem.  It pulled me back in, but pacing has always been an issue for him.  That's probably the films biggest problem because otherwise, it really works.  The action is great, the themes are great, the characters are great, and there are just some stellar moments here.  Seeing McAvoy and Stewart share a scene together still gives me chills.  It's not a perfect movie, but godamn is it a good one, and it does it's best to fix what was becoming a clustercuss of a timeline for this franchise.

X men days of future past is easily one of the best x men movies of all time and marked the return of  Bryan Singer to the franchise after several disappointment entries after his departure. Michael Fassbender, Jennifer Lawrence, and Nicholas Hault. All the performances are great notably a delightfully funny and witty small appearance by Evan Peters as Quicksilver, James McAvoys tortured performance as young xavier, and Michael Fassbenders almost superior interpretation of a young magneto rivaling  the charismatic Mcckellen. The movie sends Jackmans wolverine back to the past to meet with young xavier played Mccavoy to stop a future apocalypse. This movie is fun as it brillianly goes back to the past and present weaving between the two separate casts and trilogies in an epic way. Jackman is great with the prequel cast serving as the bridge between the two franchises. The movie has its weaknesses as the story can be devoid of logic and a lot of plot holes created by previous entries. Yet it features great drama, and lots of action that turn this movie into a superhero epic. Easily one of the best in the franchise.

I'm gonna be a little too honest here: I bingewatched all the X-Men movies, so I often forget about this movie. Many times I get confused when someone mentions a scene from this movie, and I'm like, "wait, it happened in THIS movie? I thought it happened in First Class/Apocalypse!" And I'd prefer admitting that it's my fault than it being the movie's fault.

X-Men: Days of the Future Past is what I'd call the movie that bridges X-Men: First Class with the other canonical movies, and at the same time also helps in eliminating the bad movies like The Last Stand and Origins. The movie begins with, as usual, mutants being attacked and eliminated. So to save all of them, Wolverine goes back in time and stop Mystique from killing Bolivar Trask, a defence contractor. Wolverine reached the 1970s, when he was still a mutant without vibranium. And to set planes in motion, he has to find Charlex Xavier, Magneto, Beast and Mystique.

Bolivar Trask used Mystique's powers to create Mutant Hunting Robots. In the beginning they were only meant to be used to fight in the Vietnam war, but seeing how Mystique and Magneto revealed themselves, they decided to use the robots to hunt down the mutants itself. They didn't see whether mutants are also sentient beings or not, they just wanted to have them eliminated. And that's when the roles of money and power play. It was on the order of President Nixon that Bolivar decided to make those robots, which President Nixon had ordered only because of Bolivar's influence. So in a way it was a loop of blame.

And when Professor X, Wolverine and Quicksilver reach Magneto to save him, we finally get to see the fabled Quicksilver scene, where he takes down all the prison guards single handedly. It was the most iconic moment from the movie, and no amount of appreciation can praise it as much as it deserves. The modern day scenes were also adding to the tension, and in the end when Mystique is left with the choice whether to kill Bolivar or not, it is a quite tense moment whether the mutants in the modern time will survive or not. In the end we see that all the mutants who had died in the previous movies had also come back to life, and the franchise was brought back to where Bryan Singer had left it in X2.

Normally it is very difficult to reboot a franchise (read Sonic 06). Not only do you have to understant the major events that need to ve removed in order to fix the franchise, you also have to make the reboot-turning movie really good, otherwise it will just contribute to being the hot garbage that the other movies of the franchise are. And that's the reason why I believe this movie is underrated. It single handedly fixed a failing franchise, joined the acclaimed prequel into the main timeline and became a success both critically and financiallly. It deserves to be one of the most iconic X-Men movies.

‘Days of Future Past' only seems to get better on subsequent re-viewings, and the fact that it exists in the state that it does is nothing short of spectacular. Bridging together the timeline and actors of the original films with the ‘First Class' cast works better than the film should have any right to, peaking in a beautiful scene shared by the old and young Xaviers from Stewart and McAvoy. 
‘Days of Future Past' also thrives at ramping up the stakes to unprecedented levels with its chilling time traveling storyline. The bleak neon scapes of the totalitarian dystopian future give a haunting immediacy to the slick set of events informing it in the 70's past, a period setting that is just as effectively used as in the series' previous high point, ‘First Class.' The Quicksilver scene (you know which one), the climactic culmination on both ends of the timeline, and the lovely epilogue that (if only) would've marked a perfect end to the series, all cement ‘Days of Future Past' as one of the best comic book films of all time.

Before talking about "Days of the Future Past," we have to go back to the past.
This year is 2011 and Breakwell's original X-Men trilogy takes shape by Matthew Vaughn ("Kick-Up", "Stardust"). The talented Vaughan brought together his first-class ensemble, including James McAvoy, Michael Fassbender, and Jennifer Lawrence, and created a very successful prequel for the original and beloved trilogy, whose third film and X-Men Origins: Wolverine, After him, many admirers disappointed. This introductory film presented the events that led to the rivalry between Professor X and his old friend Magneto - and he did it in a wonderful and refreshing way. Three years passed, including another film about "Wolverine" - and here we came to the sequel to the successful Freeport.
But it's really not a regular sequel. "The Future That Was," continues both the old trilogy and the "beginning," and even tries to create continuity to last year's Wolverine. The result - a salad. The film tries to be a continuation of three different films and in a way that ignores the doubt, or does it deliberately - does not attach much importance to the events of one of them. Still, as a film in itself, the plot flows and flows.

Days of Future Past does a fantastic job of balancing and pacing a time travel film which is something nearly no other filmmaker can do. The film does a great job of crafting emotional connection between its main characters, specifically between young Charles, young Eric, and Logan. These three men craft a deep connection with the audience and making them the center of the story keeps any problems a time travel movie would create (being extremely jumbled) from happening. Instead of getting a jumbled mess, we get a thrilling chase movie inside a time travel movie that has fantastic performances that creates genuine emotion and has perfect pacing. This also benefits from intrigue created from the dark tone and intensity created in the intro. As a whole there are no real flaws in a film that could have gone wrong in a lot of places. This shows extremely skilled film making and terrific acting that creates a dark but fun tone and great intensity that still has a satisfying emotional climax. (also a great score) ;)

Bryan Singer is a master storyteller. And for someone who didn't know much about the X-Men when he first took them on a decade and a half ago, I sincerely don't ever want anyone else telling their stories anymore. This movie was something I'd been waiting for from the moment I heard about it. It is plucked directly out of my childhood and seems surreal to see onscreen. I have an emotional attachment to this story. However, when I saw the first trailers, I was immensely disappointed. It did NOT look good. Well, considering the Godzilla trailers DID look good and it was a steaming pile of lizard dung, looks can clearly be deceiving. XMen DOFP is a masterpiece. Singer eradicated the ridiculous Ratner movie, cleaned up some loose ends from other films, introduced the most exciting new character, Quicksilver, and even alluded to him being the son of Magneto, as he is in the comics. I was concerned about another Wolverine-focused picture, but it worked. Very well. In fact, it was just as much a Professor X and Magneto movie, which is great considering that Michael Fassbender is a PERFECT Magneto. Cold, emotionless and focused on his mission. He has personified Magneto more than Ian McKellen ever could. I always thought they went way too old for that role and Fassbender fixes that. The complexity of the time traveling is not without its holes (like every time-traveling story), but the portrayal of the Sentinels, Trask, Stryker and Chris Claremont/John Byrne's original dystopian future was modernized as perfectly as can be. Just amazing in every way, especially if you're an XMen fan.

It's just sad to see that it's Wolverine who is going back in time and not Kitty Pryde. It would've been a perfect opportunity to give her a bigger role here. But it still works. Hugh Jackman has great chemistry with Michael Fassbenders Magneto and James McAvoys Charles Xavier. Also big parts for Jennifer Lawrence as Mystique (here way better than in First Class), Nicholas Hoult as Beast and a small but scene stealing moment for this incarnation of Quicksilver played by Evan Peters (and by Aaron Johnson in The Avengers: Age of Ultron). It's a fun ride. It's a time travel movie well made. It's handling a lot of characters very well. It's entertaining from start to finish.

The ultimate X-Men ensemble fights a war for the survival of the species across two time periods in X-MEN: DAYS OF FUTURE PAST. The beloved characters from the original "X-Men" film trilogy join forces with their younger selves from the past, "X-Men: First Class," in order to change a major historical event and fight in an epic battle that could save our future.

Coming off "X-Men: First Class", this was certainly an entirely different shift. Having already watched it once and continually watching the brutal fight scenes over and over, I finally got to sit down and re-watch the whole thing again. And while it wasn't as good as I remember it being, it's still a really solid, fun, and dark superhero film that we don't get to see too often these days. 

One thing that's fantastic about this film is just the sheer brutality and darkness of this movie. This, along with the future release of "Logan", are both examples of superhero films that are a lot more dark and brutal, but are still really fun. The fight scenes in this film looked beautiful but they were simultaneously so terrifying. The action was absolutely brutal and they didn't hold back on much. I thought that they really took advantage of the time-travel plot here, allowing them to push the limits of character fates and what they could do with them. I thought that was easily one of the best aspects of this film and it stands out from a lot of superhero films. 

Another thing that was good but I'm still conflicted about was the story. I thought the story was really interesting and thought out here but it really throws a kink in the entire universe. What this film essentially does is it makes almost every other X-Men film non-canon. That's pretty crazy and a curious decision if I say so myself. I mean, some things stay relatively the same but for the most part, the story changes things forever. And that's the thing with time travel. Time travel is so interesting but it creates so many different holes and questions. However, for the most part, I actually thought that they did a pretty good with their execution here and the story was still really captivating. 

I guess the thing I was mostly questionable on was making Magneto one of the prime villains. I understand based on his character and mindset that he would become a prime antagonist in this film, but it felt like more an annoyance than a benefit for us. When I say benefit, I guess I mean entertaining or sensible. Either way, I thought his portrayal of his character, along with everyone else's portrayal, were all really solid. Everyone, from James McAvoy, Hugh Jackman, Michael Fassbender, Jennifer Lawrence, Patrick Stewart, and everyone else, were all fantastic. It was cool to see two different periods of X-Men (Past and Present versions) on the screen at the same time. It was really fun and these are some of the best performances I've seen from some of these people in the entire franchise. 

In the end, this was certainly a fun and dark film. It's one of the better X-Men films in the franchise, if not the second best entirely.

I must admit, the trailers didn't have me convinced - and after the sour taste 'Jack the Giant Slayer' left in my mouth, I was sceptic. I really dug Matthew Vaughn's approach with 'First Class' (who had a tough task rebooting the franchise after the lacklustre 'Last Stand' and the generic, dull 'X-Men Origins: Wolverine') and I wouldn't have minded him returning at all. But as it turns out, Bryan Singer (yes, I dare speak his name) still has a few tricks up his sleeve. For its sheer scale and epic storytelling alone, 'Days of Future Past' is fantastic.

It's a shame there's so much controversy surrounding this film, but I guess whoever chooses to deprive himself willingly of such a pleasure must be fully aware that he does so at his own expense. Because this is the kind of film that made me fall in love with movies in the first place.

Yet (despite my 10-star review), it's not perfect. And it's not 'The Usual Suspects' with mutants - how could it be; this is simply not that kind of film. But I have to say that pretty much my only gripe with this movie is that it has too many characters and that some of them don't get enough screen time (or actually, there's not too many characters: there's just too many great actors playing those characters - but then again, that's half of the fun). Of all the X-men films, this has the most complex plot - and also the most interesting. Different time-lines are tricky to do and can be rather hard to follow, but thanks to a (very!) clever script with a great part for Logan, we never get lost. And that's the best news: sorely missed in the last instalment (except for a hilarious cameo), the franchise has Hugh Jackman back. And of him at least we do get to see a lot, since he really leads us through this film (giving his best Wolverine performance yet along the way). If Logan can be called the heart of the X-men, then Charles Xavier must be the mind while Magneto and Mystique provide the - slightly twisted - soul, and seeing them all together again brought a broad, stupid grin to my face (which only got broader whenever Quicksilver appeared on screen - for reasons you will have to find out for yourselves). 

What really sets the X-men films apart from the ever more derivative comic-book adaptations - at least as far as I'm concerned - is that I always genuinely cared for the characters, and 'Days of Future Past' is no exception. I love loud, spectacular action movies as much as the next guy, but if I don't get to care for the protagonists - what's the point? The reason I gave this 10 stars, and what is so exceptional these days, is that what we get here is a complex, smart Fantasy/Sci-Fi thrill-ride that respects its origins as much as it embraces the future, while never - ever - forgetting that its first job is to entertain the audience. For finding that perfect, rare balance between character-driven human drama and no-holds-barred popcorn action spectacle, 'Days of Future Past' deserves my 10-star rating (which is a first for me: I've never given 10-stars to a comic-book movie).

So my verdict: If you like to get your minds blown by something with true heart and soul, this massive 'mutant' of a film is upon you, and all you have to do is give in to the X-citement. Enjoy the ride.With its mind-boggling premise and jaw-dropping cast, X-Men: Days Of Future Past blasts into cinemas bearing the weight of great expectations. Surely this mash-up of X-Men past and future has the potential to be the best superhero blockbuster our world will ever see? Well, yes and no.

To be strictly objective, Days Of Future Past can occasionally come off as a little too earnest, its enormous cast of characters getting somewhat lost in the grinding of its narrative gears. But, when it works (which is most of the time), Days Of Future Past comes pretty darn close to nerdvana - this is a smart, rich film that effectively mines its source material (both the movies and Chris Claremont's classic 1981 storyline in the comic books) and its incredible cast for emotion, power and depth.

Flash forward to the bleakest of futures. X-Men we have known - led by perennial frenemies Professor Charles Xavier (Patrick Stewart) and Erik Lensherr/Magneto (Ian McKellen) - are being hunted mercilessly by a horde of intelligent, death-mongering robots known as Sentinels. With little hope for survival, the desperate X-Men decide to send Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) back in time to the 1970s. There, he must find the younger Charles (James McAvoy) and Erik (Michael Fassbender) - several years estranged after the traumatic events of X-Men: First Class - and get them to change the future before it can happen.

Sounds simple enough? Not really. Days Of Future Past frequently threatens to fall foul of its complicated puzzle-box of a narrative, one that involves time travel, quantum physics and a swirling mess of characters, action and motivations. There's Dr. Bolivar Trask (Peter Dinklage), creator of the Sentinel programme, whose assassination in the past by Charles' pseudo-sister Raven (Jennifer Lawrence) brings about the dystopia of the future. There are prison breaks, astral projections, and several grisly mutant deaths. Truthfully, this incredibly ambitious mix of character, plot and spectacle could very easily go horribly wrong.

What's so impressive about director Bryan Singer's return to the franchise is how well he weaves all the disparate threads of his narrative together. This is emphatically not the Singer who gave us mediocre misfires like Superman Returns and Jack The Giant Slayer. Rather, this is the work of the Singer who made his mark with films like X1, X2 and The Usual Suspects, all of which featured a masterful blend of wit and wisdom, character and story.

In Days Of Future Past, Singer skilfully plays on the schism that opened up between Erik and Charles at the end of First Class to add welcome depths of emotion to the high stakes already in play. The deep, difficult relationship between the two men has always been the fulcrum of the series, and Singer allows it to breathe and grow. With the help of McAvoy and Fassbender (not to mention Stewart and McKellen), some of the best actors in the business, the director makes it possible to believe that resentment can give way to forgiveness, and vice versa, often in the blink of an eye. McAvoy, in particular, gives a shudderingly good performance as a man called upon to help others when he's lost his own way.

With such an enormous revolving cast of characters, Singer even manages to give many - though not all - of them their hearts and souls. (Alas, Storm/Ororo, we will never know ye!) Thrust into the unlikely role of mentor to the broken, heartsore Charles, Wolverine must find a different sort of strength and ingenuity within himself. Jackman plays the role beautifully, anchoring the two timelines with charm and gravitas. Though still something of an awkward fit for her part, Lawrence, too, plays Raven's dilemma very well, as she wavers between Charles' offer of hope and Erik's often bloody single-mindedness.

But Days Of Future Past doesn't just mire itself in the toss and tumble of its characters' emotional journeys. Singer throws in a few crackerjack action sequences, opening the film with a heart-stopping massacre that very effectively underscores the dire threat posed by the Sentinels of the future. Crucially, Singer also finds the time and space within the darkest shadows of his story to have a little fun, judiciously tossing quips and sight gags into the mix - particularly in a tour de force prison break sequence, in which the preternaturally speedy Pietro Maximoff (Evan Peters), better known to comic aficionados as Quicksilver, literally runs away with the entire show.

Make no mistake about it, this is a behemoth of a film that won't go down well with everybody. Newbies will almost certainly find themselves lost, bewildered, and perhaps even bored. Singer's tale sprawls in so many directions that, if you're not at least marginally invested in the characters, it could prove to be a trying experience.

But, for everyone else, ranging from casual fans to enthusiasts and obsessives, Singer and screenwriter Simon Kinberg have crafted something truly remarkable. Steeped in history and lore, both of the cinematic and comic-book variety, Days Of Future Past feels like a dark love letter to the spirit of that original band of mutants and the message of hope, tolerance and humanity that has always accompanied their attempts to find their place on Earth.

Most remarkably of all, Days Of Future Past practically radiates a bravery and freshness that you'd never expect from the seventh film in a blockbuster franchise. Instead of playing it safe and sound, Days Of Future Past mashes up past, present and future, sweeping up a lot of what has been taken for granted in the X-Men cinematic universe and, well, chucking it out of the proverbial window. The ending of this film truly opens up an intriguing plethora of narrative possibilities that stretch in any and all directions.
