This new X-Men movie is so incredible, there's so much unique and awesome things that blew my mind of when I saw this film. The return of Brian Singer to the X-Men franchise totally is the reason why this movie is so great, which means that The Last Stand could have been great if he had direct it. Days of Future Past is one heck of a movie, and I never got bored because it's so damn well made and entertaining! The opening scene is incredible, and both the CGI and the actors are all superb.

X-Men: Days of Future Past is the best sci-fi movie of the year (to date), and one important aspect is the awesome soundtrack from John Ottman, truly a wonderful soundtrack! The best thing is of course the story, they are changing the past for a better future, and the result of that is so great, because we don't know how much have changed after the events in DoFP! That's why I can't wait until the next X-Men film! There are some downsides like vague CGI at some places, and it got a bit confusing with the time travel, but it's still an awesome movie!

It is very difficult for a superhero film to keep the interest and the momentum in the seventh instalment. But the director Bryan Singer, focusing on two time periods and Wolverine going to 1973 to save the future of mankind, he made the old fans happy and content, and new viewers could understand what the story in general is about the X-Men. The film stars the familiar cast, including Hugh Jackman, James McAvoy, Michael Fassbender, Jennifer Lawrence, Halle Berry, Anna Paquin, Ellen Page, Nicholas Hoult, Shawn Ashmore, Peter Dinklage, Ian McKellen, and Patrick Stewart.  Of course, there is not too many movies failing on a budget of US$200 million, and it this British-American co-production used some of the best names in the industry . 

Simon Kinberg wrote the screenplay from a story conceived by him, Matthew Vaughn, and Jane Goldman, and managed with the director Singer to make a best-reviewed film in the X-Men series. It had fresh visual style, story, and acting, and it was normal that finished as a highest-grossing film in the series, having earned over $746 million worldwide. A sequel, X-Men: Apocalypse, is scheduled for release on May 27, 2016, with Singer returning to direct.

I had some problem with the story at the moments... it seemed going out of control of any logic, but maybe that is normal for something dealing with the time travel and supernatural powers. Enjoyable entertainment, and nothing more.

Best movie in the series, more plot focused then pure visual extravaganza. Even a new comer to the series should like the movie and one following the series will love it as it combines the cast from the two time lines in the series. The ensemble cast are superb in their roles, the movie is well paced with easy humor on an otherwise serious story - special accolades to Evan Peters as Quick Silver. The time paradox and the ending is a marvel.

i was very disappointed in this movie after all the hype. one of the movie's biggest failings is the casting of jennifer lawrence as mystique and turning the sentinels into the liquid terminators from terminator two instead of many giant formidable robots that could be killed. two of the better characters in the movie were blink and quicksilver, but their parts were too few. peter dinklage, patrick stewart and ian mckellan were all good as usual, but the story,direction and script were mediocre. it is really about as good as all the others in the series, which is to say, flawed but mostly entertaining. the only really good entry in the x-men remains the wolverine. hugh jackman's really kind of weak in days of future past due to the unfocused and contrived plotting. i have given it three stars because i can't give it 2+3/4 stars  it deserves and because i love the superhero genre, when it's done right like watchmen, the avengers, iron man 1, and spider man 2. i actually like dc heroes better than marvel but the best d.c. shows are animated. i'm still hoping joss whedon  will take on batman with some inspired casting of unknowns, as i can't think of anyone who could do batman justice (including ben affleck. i would love to see whedon do for batman what he did for the avengers.
They brought the story back to the 2 characters who are clearly the most captivating; Magneto and Professor X. Now, why haven't they made a X-Men Origins movie about them??
A welcome return to form on the franchise with a proper reset. So good to hear the X2 theme ring in at the end.

A few continuity issues with the ealier films aside, this latest installment in Fox's X-Men franchise is easily the best since X-Men United. I actually liked it more than Marvel's The Avengers. Problem was too little time spent on new, compelling characters, like the mutant speedster, Quicksilver, who deserved more exposition. All in all, a solid effort. A warning on a double-dip, though: next year, an Extended Cut blu-ray will be released, so you may want to wait until then to buy it.

This is an interesting case where a movie is definitely enjoyed the most by those who have read lots of the comic books or at least have an extensive knowledge of all the previous movies in the franchise, and yet also can appeal to someone like me who has, at best, been a casual X-Men fan, if not, someone who is actually starting to grow tired of the franchise.  Oddly enough, this was one of the riskiest movies of the summer; Fox Studios spent over $250 million on the production budget alone, that doesn't include the millions and millions they spent on marketing the film, making this the second most expensive movie the studio has ever made (behind "Avatar"), and they chose to spend so much on the SEVENTH movie in the franchise.  Wouldn't they think audiences might not flock to see Wolverine & Co. a seventh time?  Thankfully for Fox, they were right, "Days of Future Past" is the highest grossing X-Men film in the series, but still failed to crack the $1 billion mark, and let's be honest, if you're spending upwards of $500 million on a movie, you'd like to at the very least, double what you spent on it, but it is still a blockbuster success.
 
X-men needed Bryan Singer, and Bryan Singer definitely needed X-Men.  Singer's career has been one bad move after another since he left the franchise after "X-2," and has been trying desperately to claw his way back to success, just like the X-Men franchise (while still very profitable) took a dip in quality after Singer left, so "Days" is a much needed, mutually beneficial reunion for the two of them.  There's no doubt that Singer can still make a movie with all the action thrills that summer audiences want, without sacrificing good storytelling and solid performances.  Interestingly enough, Singer does not really give his original cast much to do in this installment; a bunch of lesser-known X-Men from the first series get a cool fight scene at the beginning, without Stewart, Mckellen, Berry or Jackman, who join in after and then most of the original cast spends the rest of the movie hanging out in a dimly-lit room on top of a mountain.  The only one who gets to participate in the main story is Jackman's Wolverine (obviously, being the audience favorite), who is transported to the 1970's to stop the creation of a bunch of Terminator rip-offs from killing all the mutants.
 
Instead, the cast of "X-Men: First Class" gets most of the screen time, with Jackman still as the lead.  We see the return of Hoult, McAvoy, Fassbender and Lawrence as mutants from their origin movie.  Unfortunately, I am not enamored with any of these actors like most of the general public is; they've proven to all be pretty good but I don't love any of them.  We spend much of the movie watching them bicker with each other about what side they should be on and who's betraying who, which gets tedious after a while; either be friends or be enemies but stop yelling at each other in the middle ground; it wasn't pulled off in a charmingly funny way like in 2012's "Avengers."
 
Nevertheless, when the movie finally clicks together, it is a great thrill ride.  It works best for fans of the comics because you get introduced to a lot of mutants without too much backstory at a pretty quick pace, but if you learn to just go with it, you should be fine.  As a casual X-Men fan, I really only see these movies for Wolverine, which is why I'm often content with his solo movies; I just want to see him pop the claws and attack people.  Wolverine is still a great role for Jackman and he knows exactly how to own it and really dominate a scene, but we don't actually get too many of those classic Wolverine battles (also I hate the bone claws... really wish they could have fudged the story and thrown some metal on those bad boys).
 
Placing the mutants in actual historical events works better in this film than it did in "First Class," but there are still some moments that make you groan, (JFK was a mutant too??  Who knew??)  But in the end, "Days" is great summer fun.  It is bogged down a little by is long run time, lack of use of McKellen and Stewart, a convoluted story and those pesky bone claws.  But as I said, when all the gears are working together, you end up with incredible sequences that make this great summer fun and an above average popcorn movie that pumps some much-needed gas in a franchise that was starting to run on fumes.

When it was announced that Bryan Singer was returning to the Director's Chair for "X-Men: Days of Future Past," fanboys and girls everywhere squealed in excitement. Finally, the series was going back into the hands of the man who helped start the whole film franchise. I, on the other hand, groaned and wondered why "First Class" helmsman Matthew Vaughn couldn't return to push the story further. It was my favorite entry in the series and took the bad taste out of my mouth created by the mess referred to as "The Last Stand."

In the distant future, robots known as Sentinels have all but wiped out both mutants and humans. Wolverine is sent by the X-Men to prevent an event which will send history down this path to destruction. First he has to find a way to unite Professor X and Magneto in a search for the harbinger of doom - Mystique.

My worries over Singer's return to steer the franchise were all realized after the first hour or so of "X-Men: Days of Future Past." The first portion of the film moves ahead and sets the viewer up for a powerful and epic thrill ride. Unfortunately, like most of the director's movies, it starts to meander and get tedious right after the halfway mark. The action and excitement gets bogged down in a lot of dramatic narrative which feels as if it was injected into the script to make the movie more analytical than it really needed to be.

One thing I was pleasantly surprised by was the way the massive amount of cast members and the parts they played in the story were handled. I was concerned when it was announced that the original and new actors who portrayed their respective characters were going to be jammed into one movie. How in the world were filmmakers going to keep the movie from becoming overcrowded and derailing? 

Director Singer and Screenwriter Simon Kinberg handled the whole affair quite well. Instead of trying to cram as much of a pleasurable thing down our throats as they could, they worked towards the greater good of the whole. They didn't play favorites and shove certain popular actors into scenes just to give them more face time.

"X-Men: Days of Future Past" is rated PG-13for sequences of intense sci-fi violence and action, some suggestive material, nudity, and language. I've seen Hugh Jackman's butt enough now. Does it really have to be showcased in every one of these films?

Although I did enjoy "X-Men: Days of Future Past" to a certain degree, I felt myself getting lethargic as it moved along towards its inevitable climax. By no means is it a bad movie, but I think it could've been better under Matthew Vaughn's direction. I do give it props for fully embracing its science fiction roots.

Bryan Singer is a master storyteller.  And for someone who didn't know much about the X-Men when he first took them on a decade and a half ago, I sincerely don't ever want anyone else telling their stories anymore.  This movie was something I'd been waiting for from the moment I heard about it.  It is plucked directly out of my childhood and seems surreal to see onscreen.  I have an emotional attachment to this story.  However, when I saw the first trailers, I was immensely disappointed.  It did NOT look good.  Well, considering the Godzilla trailers DID look good and it was a steaming pile of lizard dung, looks can clearly be deceiving.  XMen DOFP is a masterpiece.  Singer eradicated the ridiculous Ratner movie, cleaned up some loose ends from other films, introduced the most exciting new character, Quicksilver, and even alluded to him being the son of Magneto, as he is in the comics.  I was concerned about another Wolverine-focused picture, but it worked.  Very well.  In fact, it was just as much a Professor X and Magneto movie, which is great considering that Michael Fassbender is a PERFECT Magneto.  Cold, emotionless and focused on his mission.  He has personified Magneto more than Ian McKellen ever could.  I always thought they went way too old for that role and Fassbender fixes that.  The complexity of the time traveling is not without its holes (like every time-traveling story), but the portrayal of the Sentinels, Trask, Stryker and Chris Claremont/John Byrne's original dystopian future was modernized as perfectly as can be.  Just amazing in every way, especially if you're an XMen fan.

This film was the victim of skepticism and fear for months after announcement. This fear was well grounded, however, after the almost universally hated "X-Men Origins: Wolverine" and "X-Men: The Last Stand" in addition to the divisive Wolverine movie released last year. Don't worry, though. It's awesome. Bryan Singer returns to the X-Men franchise after directing the first two X-Men movies but leaving after X2, which is one of the most loved superhero movies ever, to direct Superman Returns ( and that didn't work out too well for him). The announcement of his directing this newest addition to the franchise was met with relief and as soon as you hear the familiar X2 music in the film's opening, you know Singer is back and a good movie is in store. The plot revolves around Wolverine, played by Hugh Jackman, being sent back in time from an apocalyptic future where mutants have almost been entirely wiped out to find a young Charles Xavier and Eric Lensherr (otherwise known as Professor X and Magneto), played by James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender respectively, and help him change the past to save the future. This storyline is overly complex at some points, introducing plot points that have not even been raised or questioned in previous movies (how exactly is Professor X alive?) but that is because Singer has not been the only director working on this franchise and the mythology and plot has been mixed up because of this. It is an engaging and interesting story, drawing you in from start to finish. One of the X-Men movies strongest points throughout the series has been its impressive visual effects and it is no different here. The robotic Sentinels look interesting and realistic in the past but intimidating and powerful in the future while the mutant powers look as fantastic as always. One scene, however, is the clear stand-out of the film due to its style and CGI involving Evan Peters new mutant Quicksilver. It had the whole cinema laughing and, while I won't spoil it here, it is a must see. Another thing the X-Men franchise has consistently done right is it's terrific casting. Hugh Jackman is iconic as Wolverine and it is difficult to imagine anyone else playing the role at this point while James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender are worthy successors to the comic-book accurate characters portrayed by Sirs Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellan. It is very difficult to have any gripes at all with this film if you are a casual moviegoer with entertaining action sequences among all of this. This only problem I can think of which may annoy hardcore X-Men fans only but even then not a lot is the lack of fan favourite character Bishop throughout the film. Even then, this is a film that it loved generally by fans and newcomers to the series alike, boasting impressive action sequences, casting, effects and a great sense of humour which weaves in nicely with the dark sections of the film. This is a return to form for the X-Men franchise and leaves myself personally aching for more and highly anticipating the 2016 follow-up "X-Men Apocalypse."

Considering its lackluster predecessors, the missed opportunity to capitalize on anything special from the X-Meniverse... and how annoying its been having to see derivative Wolverine fodder..... finally, a movie that takes a chance to invest heavy X-Men themes with one of its most classic arcs that serves to repair the opportunity for future films (though doubtful it'll happen) all within 2 hours. Though unquestionably flawed with some plot direction, this is still the best superhero movie of the year (screw you Guardians of the Galaxy) with a pitch perfect conclusion.

I read X-Men when I was a kid. I still have a collection of the comics somewhere in boxes, of no real value since they are not MINT. I came to enjoy that series more than any other, and have seen pretty much everything from movies to animation put out with these characters, 

I enjoyed First Class. I enjoyed X-Men 1 & 2. 

Perhaps my expectations for this were too high. I found it excessively muddled and yet banal in simplicity at the same time. Playing with time, as the comic book franchise did much more effectively in the story arc of the same name, is a tricky business. In this case it completely erases any impact that a character's death has. 

Some of the iterations were visually appealing, but otherwise there wasn't much to the characters on display. Colossus, Kitty Pryde, Sunfire, Warpath, Blink, and others barely register as anything more than cut-out soldiers with CGI powers. 

Considering the budget and the quality of performers involved here, this has to be considered a failure. Anybody familiar with the best of the comic writing would surely agree.

When you go to watch this movie, don't buy popcorn at first. Instead buy it sometime in the future, travel back to that very moment and gift yourself the popcorn. I implemented this strategy and
ended up watching the movie on an empty stomach. The point of this exercise? Nothing, just as the senseless time travel shown in the film. This much anticipated installment in an otherwise 
brilliant series will leave you disappointed. That is, unless you choose not to strain your brain and just accept the events as they are. The film opens in a dark and desolate future that was set in motion in 1973, when brilliant scientist Dr. Bolivar Trask (Peter Dinklage) created a series of giant robots called Sentinels for the sole purpose of wiping out mutants, whom he claimed
were a direct threat to the human race. Prof. Xavier (Patrick Stewart) and Magneto (Ian McKellen) devise a plan to have Kitty Pryde (Ellen Page) send Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) back to the year when Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence) assassinated Trask -- it turns out that Mystique inadvertently accelerated the Sentinel program when she was subsequently captured by Sgt. William Stryker (Josh Helman), who succeeded at harvesting her DNA to make the robots more powerful than ever before. Upon arriving in the past, Wolverine sets out to change the future. In the end, the viewers are left hanging with a dilemma about the fate of the dystopian future world. It seems as if it never existed. However, if it didn't exist, none of the events in the movie would have occurred in the first place. There are plenty of other loopholes and inconsistencies that will constantly bug an observant viewer. The movie also leaves some open questions, which I hope will be resolved in
the future. For example, where does a mutant who can walk through walls (Kitty) get the power to transport people back in time? How did Wolverine get his metal claws back in the future, given that he lost them in the fifth installment? How did Xavier survive the violent disintegration previously seen in the series? On the bright side, some well directed action scenes, specially when Quicksilver saves everyone in slow motion, provides the much needed excitement one expects from an X-Men film. Towards the end, all you can hope is for the next installment, X Men: Apocalypse to be much more sensible, thrilling and satisfying than this movie
The beat film in the series

I love science fiction and I hate superheroes, but I credit the X-Men series with giving me an appreciation for them. X-Men has showed me that in the proper context, with some great writers, superheroes movies don't have to be the lowest form of sci-fi entertainment. Days of Future Past seemed to confuse some people, as it's not part of the trilogy and therefore it's timeline is off. The ending of the film also creates a paradox, which eliminates certain mistakes made in the other films. In layman's terms, some of the things that happen in the other X-Men movies, never happen, because of Days of Future Past. In an undetermined era, sometime between the end of the original film and Last Stand, a new enemy has been targeting mutants. These machines, meant to eliminate the mutants have malfunctioned and are now targeting humans as well. The machines are made with mutant DNA and therefore have the combined forces of all the mutants it's come in contact with, making them unstoppable. The only chance the X-Men have is for one of them to go back in time and stop the machines from ever being built. Wolverine is the only one with a mind strong enough to survive the trip and is sent back to the 1970s, where he meets the cast of X-Men: First Class. While difficult for non-sci-fi aficionados to understand, this film was not only extremely well written, but serves dual purposes for the series. First, it brings both casts together in an extreme fashion and it's a tremendous gift for the fans. Second, it allows the writers to undo mistakes from The Last Stand, which was at the time, set to be the final X-Men film. The ending to Days of Future Past, effectively explain that everything that happened in Last Stand, never happened, as it was part of an alternate timeline. This allows the writers to bring back characters like Prof. X (who is seen killed in that film) for possible future films. It really was an ingenious move for the franchises future, but it also allowed fans to experience the "old timers" and the "new class" working together, in a huge, diverse, and very impressive cast. Seldom are superheroes films so complicated or as well written as Days of Future Past. The writing is out of this world, the cast is full of stars, and the special effects were absolutely amazing. Love it or hate it, superheroes are part of the science fiction genre, but Days of Future Past was simply incredible and for that, it's our latest must see movie!

Despite the fact that I saw the latest installment in the X-Men franchise several months ago, it's taken me a while to actually sit down to write this review. The reasoning behind this being that I'm still a little blown away by what I witnessed in this film. I love superheroes-- you wouldn't know this from the ratings I give their movies, but I do. That's why, when I see films like The Dark Knight or Guardians of the Galaxy, I get very annoyed, because I am forced to decide what part of my critical personality to listen to. On the one hand, my geeky self tells me to love these movies unequivocally, which I try my best to do. Invariably though, my other side (the movie buff side) reminds me that pure coolness cannot compensate for bad dialogue, plotting, and acting. However, X-Men: Days of Future Past is a rare beast. It didn't make me choose.

X-Men: Days of Future Past unites the actors from the original X-Men films and the prequel film First Class in a time travel plot taken from the Uncanny X-Men comics of the 1980s. In the "not-too distant future," machines called Sentinels have taken over the world and are on a mutant killing spree, attempting to eradicate not only mutants, but humans who carry dormant mutant genes that could be passed down into future generations. To stop the Sentinels, Charles Xavier (Patrick Stewart) and Magneto (Ian McKellen) send Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) back in time to alter the past and prevent the Sentinels from being created in the first place. But before he is able to do so, he has to win the trust of the two men's younger selves (James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender, respectively). 

The premise is not only intriguing, but it's original. Marvel's movies lately have been an indistinguishable parade of galaxy-saving heroism, in which some evil device (usually one that glows with an eerie blue light) is in the clutches of a villain who plans on using it to destroy literally everything. Why? Well, we don't know. But Days of Future Past is able to bring the futuristic and sci-fi aspects of the plot into a more grounded, realistic series of situations for the characters that gives the movie real depth and weight. Of course, the fate of the world still hangs in the balance, but at times the audience is allowed to forget that, and they're caught up only in the fate of these few well-crafted characters. 

The acting and dialogue is also far better than in previous X-Men installments. Hugh Jackman is clearly still relishing in his role as Wolverine, inarguably the best character in the franchise and one of the series's better casting choices. He was sorely missed in First Class (part of the reason why that film was such a dud), and so his return to the silver screen here is more than welcome. Meanwhile, the plethora of uninteresting, underdeveloped characters from previous films have all vanished, allowing us to focus in on four very good characters: Wolverine, Magneto, Xavier, and Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence), whose ill-fated assassination attempt is the centerpiece of the plot. With Peter Dinklage giving it his all as Bolivar Trask, the diminutive creator of the Sentinel program, we have a total powerhouse of acting behind characters several films in the making.

I've been asked just why I found Days of Future Past to be so much better than other Marvel outings, and I suppose I could go through their other films one by one, detailing where they failed in places that this movie succeeded. However, the short version is simply this: Days of Future Past is the first X-Men movie in which I've enjoyed the storyline as much as the characters. Even at its best points, this franchise has been very weak when it comes to substance and story. The first X-Men film was about a mutant-making ray and a fight to the death at the top of the Statue of Liberty. X-Men: First Class incorporated mutants into the Cuban Missile Crisis. And after all this crazy, haphazard stories and loosely thought-through subplots, this fun little yarn about time travel is comparatively tame.

Final Score for X-Men: Days of Future Past: 7/10 stars. Sure, there are a good number of quibbles about dialogue and character development in this movie, but it's undeniably well-made, even looking better visually than its predecessors. This is a superhero movie done right-- No cartoony aliens, no space battles for the fate of the universe, no witless, tongue-in-cheek banter-- Just stripped-down, quality entertainment. Hopefully, the X-Men franchise will continue in the direction it's going right now, and not stumble into the pitfalls that the other, less polished films of the series did (ahem, X-Men Origins). And with Bryan Singer returning to direct the next film, it looks as if Marvel is picking things up a bit. It's not perfect in any way, but I'll give it this: This is the best superhero movie made since Iron Man. And although that's not saying much, I think it counts for something.

Though it's been almost a year since I found myself watching all the X-Men films, I can honestly can I'm a very good fan of them, enjoying almost every single film in the franchise (even when it was not enjoying favorable reaction with Wolverine's infamous debut outing). After extremely loving First Class and The Wolverine, I had no doubts that Fox was itching to compete with Marvel's success in a shared universe... but how was Fox going to pull this off? Well, first, you announce that your next movie is based off one of the most well-loved story arcs from the X-Men comics, bring Bryan Singer (who hadn't directed an X-Men film since X2 but was involved in the production of First Class) back to the director's chair, and combine the cast from the original trilogy and prequel for one all-out blockbuster. And X-Men: Days of Future Past not only succeeds in extremely demanding expectations but I also think it's the best film in the entire franchise since X2.

The film begins in the year 2023, a dark and grim future for mankind and humans combined. Advanced beings called Sentinels are ravaging the world, destroying everything in their path, despite the mutants best intentions. In one last attempt to restore balance, Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) is sent back in time to his younger self in 1973, to convince both Charles Xavier (James McAvoy) and Magneto (Michael Fassbender) to reteam together during the era they hated each other most, to prevent Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence) from triggering the assassination event that triggered mutant extinction in the first place.

With a film like Days of Future Past, in order to pull this off, Bryan Singer needed to make sure that the concept of time travel pays off, especially when the most criticized thing about the franchise are the so-called "continuity errors". Though Singer deliberately ignores the events of Origins (probably cause of the extreme hate from almost everybody; I wouldn't have cared anyway), everything told in Days of Future Past answers common confusions about the X-Men timeline. Singer also does a great job at showcasing the visual aspect between the two timelines; the dark, apocalyptic settings of the future and the colorful, bizarreness of the 1970's.

Also, in a surprising twist for the franchise, I thought it was great to see that Wolverine wasn't the main focus of the film. Though Wolverine is clearly my favorite character in this franchise, there's always other characters I felt that need to be in the spotlight for once. And Days of Future Past gives very strong character focus on different mutants this time around. Charles Xavier is extremely lone and broken from the events of First Class, with the conflict in Vietnam that forced him to close his school down, even going as far as to sacrificing his great powers in order to walk again. Magneto is trying to decide whether he should repent of his past sins in First Class or continue to go down the path he eventually takes. And finally, the main focus of the film, in my book, Mystique (my second favorite character in the franchise I might add), has to make the ultimate choice; kill the person that leads to mutant extinction or change the course of history and possibly alter some events in the franchise that angered many fans, particularly from The Last Stand.

And continuing on from Singer's brilliant styles he used from the original two X-Men films, Singer cleverly makes sure the drama is well-done before bringing the action together. Again, Singer does it again! I would go as far to say that Days of Future Past goes as far as provide the most emotional levels of the franchise, something that The Last Stand lacked. Whenever a mutant dies in this movie (and I will say, the mutant body count is extremely high in this film), no matter which one it is, the amount of emotions that carry out in the scene just flat-out delivers. There's also an extremely brilliant ending that raises many questions like great sci-fi does. When the action does kick in, it's as awesome as that phenomenal raid scene in X2! The opening battle with the Sentinels rocks, a prison breakout scene is delightfully entertaining (with a new character Quicksilver having the most memorable scene in the whole movie), and the climax, with battles taking place between 1973 and the future, is intense and emotionally resound as I mentioned.

Carrying on, Days of Future Past features some of the best acting in the franchise thus far. From the get-go, when seeing actors from the original trilogy like Patrick Stewart, Ian McKellen, Halle Berry, Ellen Page, and Shawn Ashmore return on the big-screen just rocked! Though it's the other performances that really bring the best out of this movie. Hugh Jackman continues his awesomeness as Wolverine, even when he's more of a diplomat in this than the antihero we are used to in previous films. The new additions are great to, which includes Peter Dinklage as the creator of the Sentinels, Evan Peters as Quicksilver (Aaron Taylor-Johnson will have a tough time topping this portrayal in the upcoming Avengers movie), and Mark Camacho doing an awesome imitation of President Richard Nixon. But it's the First Class cast that really make the film stand out most, which includes James McAvoy's emotional trauma, Michael Fassbender's way of causing mass chaos, and Jennifer Lawrence showcasing more grace in every new film she's in (Mystique might be better than Katniss, I don't know, I kind of like the blue makeup).

John Ottman does two jobs in Days of Future Past; he provides the score while also doing the final editing. As an editor, he successfully provides the film with a brisk pace that works for these blockbusters. As a composer, boy does he deliver. When his X2 theme is played during the title sequence, that scene alone made me realize that this was going to be a spectacular motion picture. His score does go into Hans Zimmer territory (there's one moment during the closing credits that sounds almost like the extremely talked about track "Time" from Inception), but it really adds up the emotional levels delivered in the film.

X-Men: Days of Future Past is simply phenomenal. 100% phenomenal. Bryan Singer's return to directing the franchise clearly paid off, bringing back a powerful story with powerful themes, combined with a strong visual storyline, amazing characterization and action, and one of the best modern endings I've seen in a while. With Singer directing the sequel, X-Men: Apocalypse, and James Mangold returning for the next Wolverine outing, it's safe to say that the X-Men franchise is in extreme competition with the Marvel Cinematic Universe (heck, I even think this tops The Winter Soldier as my favorite superhero film of 2014; sorry Marvel), and that the franchise won't go away anytime soon.

Where Michael Fassbender stole the show in the previous film X-Men: First Class, it is James McAvoy as the damaged and emotionally distraught Charles Xavier that steals the show in this film. Baby, if you thought that "X-Men: Last Stand" hauled in a whole heap of mutants, well, here is an ensemble "X-Men" epic that... we can all agree is rewarding. My controversial opinions on the installments in this series aside, it took two critical disappointments, and two reasonably well-received installments that still weren't considered "X2" before Bryan Singer decided to finally come home to the director's chair, which I reckon makes this the ultimate fan service to those who are into the "X-Men" film franchise. I don't know if it's the definitive "X-Men" film, but it is pretty much the definitive follow-up, because it's a sequel to a sequel and a prequel... or something like that. Amazing how this series has been through six installments before getting to this ensemble epic that tries to figure out how to tie all of those installments from multiple time angles, and it's still not as convoluted as "X-Men: The Last Stand". Yeah, I liked that film quite a bit, but it was exhausting, and with this film, well, I don't know if its talk of traveling back and forth in time to form a mutant army that could save the world is so much confusing, as much as it's trippy, so it's only fair that this title is a serious rip off an album by The Moody Blues. Look, Marvel nerds, this comic story from the '80s came out long after the classic "Days of Future Passed" album from 1967, and as far as I know, no official interpretation of this storyline ever takes place before the 1970s, so we proggers were here first. Well, you Marvel dudes have plenty of cool stuff, too, including this film, which is plenty of fun, though might try a little too hard to be at times.

Tonal unevenness has been a much bigger issue in other Marvel properties which are somewhere in this vein of seriousness, and when there is fluff in this film, it's usually clever enough to not contradict the relative intelligence, but the humor does feel forced when we come to occasions in which either the brow lowers a touch too much, or a height in tension is suddenly broken by lightheartedness. Those moments are rare, but distinct, like moments of focal unevenness in this segmented film, which changes around characters' presence, motivations and roles (Seriously, how many times is Magneto going to go from good to bad?) in a manner that is conceptually organic, but doesn't entirely sell, possibly because the film spends a touch too much time fleshing out individual layers. In a couple ways, this film forces its way to a runtime of almost two hours and a quarter, and in a lot of other ways, the structure of the storytelling is fairly tight, so the fat around the edges is a subtle issue that ends up going a long way, just like the inconsistencies in tone and focus, and, well, the natural shortcomings. When it comes to Marvel film franchises I've always been particularly fond of the "X-Men" series, because it's always had a weight and meat to it that makes for strong drama, in addition to sound entertainment value, and yet, at the end of the day, this is still technically blockbuster fluff, and this installment is technically blockbuster fluff, being reliant on sheer momentum and action that limit some degree of depth, which still stands firm, but cannot truly thrive with storytelling this accessible and, well, familiar. Throughout its course, this film suffers from subtle issues that go a long way, but there is a certain issue that is prominent through and through, and that is, of course, familiarity, for this film follows many of the same themes and motifs of its predecessors, arguably a smidge lazily, resulting in a predictability that further loosens this affair's grip. That grip is firm throughout the course of this very rewarding blockbuster, thus making for yet another worthy note in the "X-Men" film franchise that, well, still neglects to really flesh out a formula that is rich with potential, but has to dial itself down through tonal unevenness and natural shortcomings, whose restraints are reinforced by structural shortcomings and sheer familiarity. Nevertheless, more of the same is far from a bad thing in this series, and sure enough, this effort consistently entertains as a tight fusion of fluff and depth, complete with intelligence and, of course, quality stylistic proficiency.

Even musical style is fairly sharp with this film, because even though there aren't a whole lot of delightfully timely tunes in this film which is set largely in the 1970s, the soundtrack consistently entertains, with John Ottman adopting most all the right formulas with modern, pseudo-electronic scoring sensibilities whose range encompasses enchanting softs spots and gripping sweep. Also basic, but in the right way is Newton Thomas Sigel's gorgeous and dynamic cinematography, whose crisp definition and immersive scope make for some solid eye candy, almost as much as the top-notch visual effects, which are convincing and lavishly flashy, growing more and more expansive as the plot grows grander and grander. The technical value of this blockbuster seems to mirror the ambitions of the story, because a lot of the stylistic attributes are somewhat subtle, just as a lot of the story, thematically originated by Chris Claremont and John Byrne, and reinterpreted by Jane Goldman, Simon Kinberg and Matthew Vaughn, is more about action than genuine dramatic depth, yet where the style is always solid, the substance is always solid, whether it be a fun and dynamic, if occasionally uneven adventure through time and other distinguished environments, or a weighty drama that's unafraid to establish high consequences as a portrait on prejudice, warfare and humanity. Kinberg, as writer, may have to tone a lot of things down, but he still does a strong job of exploring the range of this narrative, breaking tension with a generally sharp and memorable sense of humor, whose wit thrives on strong dialogue which never abates, even when Kinberg gets extensive with his exploring the plot's themes and depths, largely through rich and well-motivated and nuanced characterization that goes brought to life by solid performances. From the charismatic, if unevenly used Patrick Stewart and charming, if awkwardly dismissed Evan Peters, to the convincing Peter Dinklage, there are a few minor roles which endear when given the opportunity, and when it comes to the more major cast members, the lovely Jennifer Lawrence, commanding Michael Fassbender and charismatic Hugh Jackman are as effective as always, while James McAvoy, in his humanly layered and emotionally charged portrayal of a young Professor Charles Xavier who must face his pains and fears for the good of those he cares most about, and of the human and mutant races alike, steals the show in his stretching boundaries of acting standards in films like these like he usually does, but these are merely the highlights of a consistently engaging cast which helps in bringing life to Kinberg's vision for a high-profile action drama, almost as much as a certain man who "X-Men" fans have been waiting for too long to see return to the director's chair. Bryan Singer makes a booming comeback to this franchise and proves to be far from rusty in his trademark tight blend of style and substance, showcasing quality technical proficiency that particularly shines in the context of stellar and sometimes surprisingly brutal action sequences, while keeping up an airtight pace that entertains thoroughly and consistently, until Singer takes on the audacity to take up dramatic thoughtfulness, which captures the tension and weight of the conflicts and themes with anything from an enthralling sense of uncertainty, to piercing resonance. There are moving moments here and there throughout this opus, though the film is never less than compelling, and if all else fails, the fun factor is never lost, firmly securing your attention, while your investment is firmly secured by the typical proficiency in style and substance that has defined this series from beginning, and defines yet another rewarding installment in the "X-Men" film saga.

Once the nights in white have reached their end (Proggers were here first!), tonal and focal unevenness, a problematic length, and even natural shortcomings to a story concept that is driven by action as much as it is driven by depth are subtle shortcomings which go a long way in rendering this formulaic feature just another installment in a franchise that has rewarded time and again, and continues to reward, because through a grand soundtrack, gorgeous cinematography, stellar visual effects and action, and a story whose tight blend of adventurous fluff and weighty dramatics is done justice by an intelligent script, memorable performances and inspired, consistently well-paced and sometimes resonant direction, "X-Men: Days of Future Past" rewards as a fun and compelling sequel and prequel to a prequel, sequel and spin-off... and so on and so forth.

3/5 - Good

I was never all that big into the X-Men series but X-Men first class and Days of  Future past exceed all expectations I ever had for a series based on a comic book.  The characters are so well developed and the line between villain and hero is grey and thought provoking. Even though it's based on a series we've all heard and seen a million times it manages to be somehow completely fresh and with ingenious mini displays of their abilities.  There are moments where they reference other X-Men movies in between but they still can stand alone even if you haven't watched them before.  It succeeds both in being the expected action adventure superfluous entertainment but also as a character study that manages to explore the struggles with their own humanity and how they choose to use their abilities (the bit with Quicksilver is brilliant).  The best movies of the genre that I know of along with Dark Knight and Watchmen.

The latest X-Men movie starring Wolverine, and the other apparently less important ones, heads in the right direction with a strong first half but unfortunately finishes with a more formulaic, less impressive finale. 

'X-Men: Days of Future Past' opens in a bleak futuristic landscape before leading into an entertaining battle between X-Men and Sentinels, powerful machines created to exterminate mutants. This interestingly sets up the subsequent events which send Wolverine back in time to prevent this dark reality, automatically giving audiences a higher expectation than they would have had with the other X-Men instalments. The humour is initially really good and there is a decent showcase of special abilities, with mutants such as Quicksilver and Blink being used productively. The story, although with its fair share of plot-holes thanks to the always ridiculous time-travel theories, also suffices in connecting members of the First Class with the original cast. Despite the solid start and hints at something a bit different, the climax resorts back to the tiresome 'Professor X v Magneto' dynamic. It appears to me that the original trilogy and First Class covered the conflict between the 'peaceful resolution' methods of Professor X and the 'any means necessary' Magneto philosophy and now it's time for a movie completely new. Furthermore, it is not obvious whether we should disregard the events from the original trilogy. And what about 'Wolverine:Origins'? Sources and Old Professor X's appearance seem to suggest yes but then we have references to Wolverine's torture in 'X2' and the presence of many of the original cast to offer contradictions. The creators got exposed for not thinking about the whole X-Men movie universe thoroughly. 

'X-Men: Days of Future Past' is an enjoyable entry thanks to its likeable cast and  enthralling first half but they missed the chance to take it to new heights by retreading on familiar ground. Saying that, depending how you feel about 'X2', it is arguably the best X-Men movie so far.

I give credit to McAvoy for his performance, he had to most meat to work with and swallowed it up.

Hard to believe that in its fifth installment of sorts X-MEN still has a good story in it.  But with just enough inventiveness, pitting characters from the past with their present, albeit their own alter egos, the latest 'episode' is actually intriguing to follow and exciting to watch. X-MEN: DOFP is one film that can almost fully justify its length at over two-hours.  The fun of watching iconic Stewart & McKellen exchange zippy dialogue is only surpassed by the intensity of fine young actors McAvoy and Fassbender playing youthful versions of  Xavier and Magneto.  It's true that other than Jackman who's there because the producers are cashing on his Wolverine popularity, the rest of the recognizable cast seems wasted in two-dimensional roles, but then again at least this time its a sacrifice made in favour of a solid story.
This movie met the high expectations by combining what these movies did right with the knowledge of what they did wrong.

A movie that could've benefited from a longer running time, X-Men: Days of Future Past is still amazingly good and fun while it lasts.

Taking out the bad of the way first: How the flying feck did Kitty got her new power?!?! 'Cause it's kind of a big deal for the movie and no explanation whatsoever was given. It causes a wrong impression at first and I was immediately put off by this aspect being thrown out of the window. 

The villain just isn't doing much there is it? Dinklage is an amazing actor and he's pretty much repeating the same speach on every scene he's in. A wasted potential, though his motivations come across on a very short but elusive speech. Also, he seems to have a power no one noticed: he teleports from Vietname to Washington in one scene. Amazing! Take that Quicksilver.

A movie so centered around Mystique doesn't have enough Mystique. And one it does, Jennifer Lawrence looks so bored it turns her scenes into a slog at times. What the hell happened?

The good stuff is actually really good. Not only does the movie try to correct the mistakes of movies past (Ha!) but it creates an evolving story, with plenty of awesome cameos, little smirks to the viewer, good dialogue, well realized world (that once again connected really well with real life events), great acting and more awesome chemistry between the young Xavier and Magneto. 

I bet there's a longer running time somewhere, because the movie felt very chopped in places, and with so many characters and new mutants around with such cool powers, it's a shame we didn't get to learn a bit more from them.

The parell world story telling can never get better than this and again the A list casting with a supporting script that entertains,I would say easily one of the interesting movies of this year.  The visual effects are mind blowing and stunning with the vibrant colors.

Marvel brings the seventh X-Men installment and second prequel in the series with X-Men Days of Future Past.

It is a very fitting title, reuniting with director Bryan Singer who did the first ever X-Men film, and with Singer brings a connected and comprehensible plot consistent with the rest of the X-Men franchise.

It is nearing the hopeless end of the mutant war in present time and humanity is frantic, at a critical and pivotal point, at the start of X-Men Days of Future Past. The remaining X-Men send Wolverine back in time to right the wrong of the past that set the course for this destructive terminus.

What follows is a suspenseful, powerful and action-packed flick that is sure to please fans. Hugh Jackman's Wolverine has always been the anchor to the film franchise and it is befitting that he is the hopeful savior in Days of Future Past and a welcoming addition. All other actors, most of them playing roles portrayed by other actors, inhabit their roles successfully. Jennifer Lawrence is the most awkward of all, especially depicting Mystique's cold malice but brought out the humanity of Raven nicely.

The story that follows is flawless and perfectly incorporated into the X-Men's universe, fitting seamlessly into currently known history of its characters as already presented in film. To that I owe Jane Goldman, the story writer, and Simon Kinberg, the screenplay writer, distinction. At first I was a bit confused whether I was to be concerned and emotionally invested but within fifteen minutes everything became clear. The story is surprisingly uncomplicated despite having time-travel as a core subject and has a well formed grasp on its direction.

With any X-Men film there are bound to be action sequences and they are particularly spellbinding in X-Men Days of Future Past. They harnessed the mutant characters' abilities to accentuate the battles instead of exploiting them for the typical detracting 'wow' factor effect. I found them especially believable and well choreographed.

Audiences love X-Men films because at their core they are about unjust persecution for being different. We all like to think we are unique and looming is the sense that eventually it could be us on the wrong side of discrimination. The sentiment of X-Men Days of Future Past reflects this theme most evidently of all the films and should be a hit with audiences.

Its completely driven by its characters and thats what makes it stand out so much. Featuring outstanding performances from James McAvoy, Jennifer Lawrence and Hugh Jackman as well as having a great supporting cast, Days of Future Past corrects ant previous mistakes made in this franchise. There's also quite a few surprising cameos as well.

From silly things like making Mystique more significant than she should have been considering the plot (but hey, let's cash in on that Hunger Games craze right now) to a young professor X wallowing in self pity and depression for at least half of the film, I cannot say this is anywhere near being the best X-men film.  Honestly, I think it's second to last with First Class getting the bottom spot.  This may not be a popular opinion, but I surely have good reasons to back it up.  The Quicksilver montage bit was one of the best parts of the film, and it did come together towards the end, but that wasn't enough to save it for me.  By that time I was already tired and about ready to leave the theater.  I think it's funny how people rip on X-men 3 but they loved this.  Until this film, that was the most successful X-men movie, and they totally tipped off everything that worked well about that film to get their success with this one.  LOL.  Anyway, no matter what material he's given, Hugh Jackman always brings it as Wolverine, and this film definitely needed more Storm doing some awesome stuff.  Blink was interesting too, but she didn't get much coverage aside from them conveniently using her powers in action shots.  

Final Analysis:  This is not a movie worth going to the theater for.  Rent it on Redbox.  

Grade: C minus

"Just because someone stumbles and loses their way doesn't mean they're lost forever." That's a quote from the latest X-Men movie, X-Men: Days of Future Past. Interestingly enough, those words could also apply to the film's director, Bryan Singer. He's a talented guy, but once upon a time, Singer lost his way.

The comic book movie age of today actually started 14 years ago, and Bryan Singer deserves a lot of the credit. He came out with X-Men in 2000. At the time it was a new take on comic book movies. Prior to X-Men, most (or all) were campy, poorly made, or both. But in X-Men, the tone was darker, the production quality was higher, it was more grounded in reality and the movie took itself seriously. And this was clear from the beginning. The film cast serious talent, and its opening scene was in Nazi-occupied Poland after all. It was well received by critics and audiences alike, and it became the patriarch of the comic book movie age.

A few years after X-Men, Singer came out with its sequel, X2: X-Men United. It was also well received by critics and audiences. Singer started work on a third installment, but then left the film to work on Superman Returns. That decision is where he stumbled and lost his way, because Superman and X-Men both suffered in the process. Superman Returns was not successful enough to reboot that franchise, and X-Men: The Last Stand was viewed as a disappointment by pretty much everyone. It didn't get any better from there either. After The Last Stand came X-Men Origins: Wolverine, also a disappointment.

The X-Men series didn't die, though, and it didn't reboot itself either. It just started making better movies, starting with X-Men: First Class, and then with The Wolverine. But no X-Men film since X2 has had Singer in the director's chair. Even with First Class turning around the series in a positive way, many have been yearning for Singer to return, believing he has an understanding of the material that others do not. In the latest installment, Days of Future Past, Singer returns to the director's chair in what is billed as the biggest X-Men film yet. There is a ton of hype around this film. As a general rule fanboys (of anything) kind of bother me, but are they right this time around? Does Singer really have 'The Midas Touch' when it comes to the X-Men? Is it worth all the hype?

Full disclosure, I like the X-Men. There are really only two types of guys - those who like comic books and those who lie. Growing up, I never really got into Superman, Spiderman or Batman. It was X-Men for me, thanks to its Saturday morning cartoon, so if there was only one movie I was looking forward to this year, this would be it. I'm not unbiased, but I'll do my best to still be fair.

That wasn't the shortest prologue of all time, so let's get right to it. Should you see X-Men: Days of Future Past? This is an easy one.. Yes! To the uninitiated, it's good. The production quality is great. Its story is good and interesting, its cast is great, and you needn't have seen the other six films to enjoy it. To fans of X-Men (even those with just a passing interest), it is great. Fanboys were right about Singer, and Days of Future Past more than validates their strong desire for his return. I'm not exactly sure of the best way to articulate this point, but he just makes everything fit together in a way that no one else has in the X-Men universe. This is the seventh film in the franchise, and somehow Singer was able to tie all six prior films together, which is an unbelievable achievement.

Some might scratch their head at what I just said, thinking this is only the fifth X-Men installment, but it really is the seventh because the Wolverine movies count too. With the exception of First Class, Wolverine is the main character of every film. He is the only character to be in all seven films (unless you count the post-credits scene of The Wolverine, in which case Xavier has also been in all seven films). In the X-Men film universe, there are really only three characters that have significant character arcs - Xavier, Magneto and Wolverine. First Class built on the character arcs of the Xavier and Magneto, but every other film was way more about Wolverine than anyone else. In Days of Future Past, Singer combined the arcs of all three in a sensible and satisfying way. And he even threw in a bunch of small stuff that enriches the movie further. For instance, Wolverine had one line in First Class, and Singer was even able to pull that into this story in a way that made sense.

Let's talk about what this movie is actually about. In the X-Men universe, there are people with special powers, and they are not so affectionately known as "mutants." Many "normal" people fear mutants, for the simple reason that people fear what they do not understand. One of the staples of the comics are "Sentinels" - giant robots that hunt mutants. Sentinels were teased in The Last Stand in two ways - you saw the head of a Sentinel after Wolverine decapitated it in a combat simulation, and Boliver Trask (the creator of the Sentinels) had a small role in the film. Both teases were unsatisfying and didn't give the staple its due justice. Other than that, there have been no Sentinels in the X-Men films. Until Days of Future Past, that is, which is all about Sentinels - Sentinels in the past, Sentinels in the future, they're everywhere.

The film starts in a post-apocalyptic future where mutants have lost everything. They've either been killed or placed in mutant internment camps. There are still some familiar mutants, but their days are numbered. One of those familiar mutants is Wolverine, who finds a way to transfer his consciousness back in time to his younger self. The plan is to stop the Sentinel program in the past so it never grows to wipe out mutants in the future. Wolverine can't do this alone, though, so once he is in the past he must bring the X-Men together to stop the war from ever starting.

The best part about this movie is the characters and the relationships between them. The acting is great and they play off of each other very well. As mentioned earlier, the X-Men series didn't do a reboot even after it produced a few duds, and it didn't need to. Even throughout the duds, the character arcs that took place were good enough to keep the series going. Also, it would be quite difficult (or impossible) to find a better Logan/Wolverine that Hugh Jackman and a better Xavier/Professor X than Patrick Stewart. They kind of make the series un-reboot-able for the time being. In Days of Future Past, once again Wolverine is the main character, and Jackman is as good as ever in the role. If you read my review of The Wolverine, you know that I mentioned that one of its strong suits was how likeable Wolverine has become. I know I'm repeating myself here, but he's even more likeable this time around. Jackman has executed the character arc of Wolverine pretty flawlessly. He's always been a good guy, but when we first saw him in X-Men, he preferred being a lone wolf to being part of a team (and being a leader was certainly out of the question). He has grown quite a bit since then, though, to the point in Days of Future Past where he, not Xavier, is leading the X-Men. It's very interesting to see this play out on the big screen, and Jackman deserves a ton of credit here. Even as Logan has grown, he has not lost the essence of what makes him The Wolverine.

There are literally too many stars in this film to go through one-by-one, so I'll cover most of them with a blanket statement that everyone does a nice job. The other most notable ones are James McAvoy as the young Xavier, Michael Fassbender as the young Magneto and Jennifer Lawrence as Mystique. McAvoy does a great job and gives us a side of Xavier than we've never seen before. Fassbender is once again great as Magento. As a character, Magneto has always been somewhat likeable and somewhat unlikeable. He is more unlikeable in this one than he was in First Class, but I think he's supposed to be and you still understand his motivations which is key. And the contrast between him and the older Magneto (Ian McKellan) helps to make Magneto pretty likeable in the future. The character of Mystique has a large role in this film, which is great because it means we get to see Jennifer Lawrence wearing nothing but blue body paint for a good portion of the film. But it's also good because she does a nice job in that role and you can feel the chemistry and tension between her and McAvoy.

Days of Future Past hasn't received much criticism and it shouldn't, but one area where there has been a little criticism is with the villain. Some critics seem to think that Boliver Trask is lacking as a villain, but this criticism isn't really fair. Peter Dinklage does a fine job in the role, so he's not the problem, but Trask isn't the problem either. We don't learn too much about Trask and he doesn't have a lot of screen time, but that's because he's not really the villain. He's not a great guy but is he really the villain? The Sentinels are more villainous than him, but they're not really the villain either. The real villain is fear. That may seem strange or abstract, but what our heros are really fighting against is fear and what people and mutants do when they are afraid. The film is about facing fear and rising above it, which is why criticizing Trask doesn't make too much sense.

The tone of this movie is also very good. It's dark, but not too dark, and takes itself seriously. There is also some pretty good comedy in this movie. It works because it's situational and not slapstick, and it is usually born out of the relationships between characters. It does not detract from the seriousness of the movie. The pacing isn't bad but I wouldn't say it's great. I think Singer is a talented guy, but pacing has never been his strongest suit. He likes to build things up and allow them to develop (which is a good thing), but in comparison to what audiences are used to, it may seem to be a little slow at times. Overall this isn't a bad thing, because it means he's not throwing in action for the sake of action. At the same time, to be fair I must mention that some films do a better job with pacing while still allowing things to develop (Batman Begins and Iron Man come to mind). Fast or slow, there are a lot of nice scenes in this movie. There is powerful dialogue and good use of voice-overs.

One thing that is abundantly clear upon leaving the theater is that the future of the X-Men film series has never looked brighter. Singer has made a very good movie here, and because he was able to pull together all the prior stories, the duds of the series should be a little more palatable since now we can see that they ultimately lead to something greater. I imagine now the focus will primarily be on what is to come, instead of on things like remembering how much they fucked up Deadpool in X-Men Origins. There have been a few continuity problems in the X-Men film series. In The Last Stand, Boliver Trask was a big black guy. In Days of Future Past, he's a little white guy who Buddy The Elf thinks ran away from the North Pole. But that's small stuff which is forgivable if you get the big stuff right. In fact, this movie totally ignores some of the smaller stuff which is fine. Things like, how is Xavier alive? Watch the post-credits scene of The Last Stand if you really want to know. How does Wolverine have metal claws again? Who cares? He's buddies with Magneto now, so use your imagination. The point is that neither of those things actually matter to this movie. By not wasting time on the small stuff, Singer made sure to keep the main thing the main thing. As a whole, the series has always gotten the big stuff right, which is to say they got Professor X, Magneto and Wolverine right.

As for Days of Future Past, it gets just about everything right. See this movie! This is quite possibly the best film in the X-Men franchise. I'm having a hard time deciding if it's the best comic book movie of the year. Both it and Captain America: The Winter Soldier are very good, if not great. I'm going to give the nod to X-Men, but like I said earlier, I'm biased.

rt_summary: Convinced that mutants pose a threat to humanity, Dr. Bolivar Trask (Peter Dinklage) develops the Sentinels, enormous robotic weapons that can detect a mutant gene and zero in on that person. In the 21st century, the Sentinels have evolved into highly efficient killing machines. With mutants now facing extinction, Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) volunteers to go back in time and rally the X-Men of the past to help change a pivotal moment in history and thereby save their future.
